“She came close once, but they ended up calling off the engagement.” Sighing, Mackenzie said, “She met someone at Collin’s wedding, they seem happy together.”

“Just so long as he takes care of her and makes her happy.” With that, Mac burst out laughing; so I said, “What’s so funny?”

“Oh right, I keep forgetting this is all new to you.” Composing herself, Mac said, “Carrie came out a year after you vanished.”

“So Carrie’s a lesbian?” pausing, I said, “Huh, I never would have figured that would be true.”

“I’m sure they’ll all come to visit when they have the chance; just remember, they’ve got jobs now.” Leaning forward, Mac said, “As much as they’d love to, they can’t just drop everything.”

“I’ll try to remember that.” I suddenly realized something, “Wait, you haven’t told me about Eric. What's he been up to?"

Mac was silent for a while; until she said, “I’m afraid I can’t tell you; that’s something between the two of you.”

"Come on, Mac, we're talking about my best friend.” Growing concerned, I said, “Why won’t you talk about him?”

“Sorry Brian; its just...your friend’s been through a lot; it’s just best if the two of you talk.”

I couldn't understand it. Why didn't Mac want to tell me about my best friend?
1112111.title: Being Brought Up To Speed

11121111.content:
I didn’t have much time to dwell on what could’ve happened to Eric; because, not even five minutes later, the doctor walked in. Closing the door, he came over to my bedside and said, “My name is Dr. Palmer.” Pausing, he looked at me and said, “You’ve given us quite a mystery, young man.”

Letting out a frustrated sigh, I said, “Tell me about it.”

Giving me a somewhat annoyed look, Mac quickly turned her attention to Dr. Palmer. “Is there anything you can tell us, doctor?”

“I’m sorry, but who are you?”

“I’m Mackenzie Hawkins.” Gesturing to me, she said, “Believe it or not, I’m his younger sister.”

“I see.” Looking at his tablet, Dr. Palmer said, “All our tests can confirm that you are, in fact, Brian Hawkins.”

“I could have told you that, Doctor.” Frustrated, I said, “Can’t you tell us something we don’t know? Like where I’ve been for the last 15 years?”

“I’m afraid that’s outside of my area of expertise, Mr. Hawkins.” With a pause, Dr. Palmer said, “All I can tell you is that you’re in perfect health.”

Breathing a sigh of relief, Mackenzie said, “Well that’s good news; considering he’s been missing for 15 years.”

“You don’t understand, Ms. Hawkins; your brother isn’t just in perfect health, he’s in better shape than he was 15 years ago.”

Mac and I were both understandably confused. Looking at the doctor, I said, “What do you mean, Doctor?”

“Do you remember being admitted to the hospital after a zip-line accident?”

That incident wasn’t something I’d be able to forget anytime soon; I was halfway down the line with the rig snapped and I felt 25 feet to the ground. When I finally regained consciousness at the hospital, I learned that I had a TBI and several skull fractures. “That’s not something you’d easily forget, Doctor.”

“Of course, that was a stupid question to ask.” pulling up a series of images on his tablet, Dr. Palmer said, “The image on the left is from after your accident, you can see the fractures in your skull. The image on the right was taken after you were brought in last night; you’ll see no sign of the fractures.”

Mac and I looked at both the images; the fractures were visible in the first image, but I couldn’t see them at all in the second. Baffled, I looked at the doctor and said, “How is that possible?”
11121111.title: The Doctor

111211111.content:
“I’m afraid that I’m at a complete loss here.” Grabbing the tablet back, Dr. Palmer said, “To my knowledge, nothing like this has ever happened before.”

“What hasn’t happening before? The fractures healing on their own or that I haven’t aged at all in 15 years.”

“Well...both actually.” Looking at me, Dr. Palmer said, “If it wasn’t for the DNA and fingerprints being a match, I never would’ve believed you were Brian Hawkins.”

“I know it’s out of your field of expertise, Doctor; but is there anything you can do to help us?” gesturing to me, Mac said, “I’d like to know, and I’m sure my mom would as well, where my brother’s been for the last 15 years.”

“I’m afraid I wouldn’t even know where to begin; since outside of science fiction, nothing like this has happened before.” Taking a breath, Dr. Palmer said, “If I may offer one tiny bit of advice; don’t look gift horses in the mouth. Ms. Hawkins, you have your brother back safe and sound; loads of families would love to get that chance.”

Mac and I looked at each other for a moment; as we both realized Dr. Palmer was right. Turning back to Dr. Palmer, Mac said,
“You’re right, doctor; I should be happy to have my brother back.” Pausing, she said, “Eventually I’m sure we’ll try to figure out what happened; but in the meantime, we’ll try to get on with our lives.”

“That’s the best advice I can give you.” Smiling, Dr. Palmer said, “I understand your parents are on their way here; I’ll be back to speak with them once they arrive.”

After Dr. Palmer left, I looked at Mac and said, “So, what should we do now?”

“It’s funny; all I could think about for the last 15 years was what we’d talk about if I ever saw you again.” Looking at me, as she paced around the room, Mac said, “But now that I have the opportunity, I can’t think of anything to talk about.”

“Well, you told me all about my friends; except for Eric.” Moving around in bed, I said, “Why don’t you tell me what Emily’s been up to?”
111211111.title: A Mystery

1113.content:
I breathed a sigh of relief when I saw Mackenzie standing in the doorway, but that relief soon turned to shock when I saw her left wrist was in a cast. Looking at her, I said, “Mac, are you okay? What happened to your wrist?”

“Huh?” looking at me, Mackenzie said, “My name’s Allison, mister.”

“That’s not your best attempt at a joke, Mac; but it’s a good try.” Chuckling, I said, “Seriously though, what happened to your wrist?”

“I’m not joking, Mister; my name’s Allison.” Pausing, she said, “The hospital called my mommy and told her to come here.”

I was starting to grow concerned that something was wrong with Mackenzie; she seemed certain that her name was Allison. Add to that the fact that she was calling our mom ‘mommy;’ which she hadn’t done in years, I was certain something wasn’t right here. If it wasn’t for the fact that she looked exactly like Mackenzie, I would’ve figured the girl was confused. My confusion only grew when a woman in her 30s, wearing a business suit, walked into the room.

The woman gave me a surprised look before turning her attention to Mackenzie. “Allison, sweetie, I told you to wait out in the hall.”

“Sorry, Mommy.”

What is going on here? Once the girl left the room, I turned to the woman said, “Who are you? Why are you calling my sister Allison?”

“This is going to sound crazy, Brian; but please hear me out.” Closing the door to the room, the woman said, “As impossible as it sounds; I’m Mackenzie. You’ve been missing for over 27 years.”
1113.title: A Little Girl

11131.content:
There was no way this woman was telling the truth; she had to be part of some prank my folks were playing on me. “I’ll give you an A for effort; but, whoever you are, you need to make yourself sound more convincing.” Looking at her, I said, “Now seriously; who are you, and where is my family?”

“God, I forgot how stubborn you could be; you’re worse than my own kids.” With an exasperated sigh, the woman said, “I’m telling you the truth, Brian; it’s April 3rd, 2041 and I’m your sister Mackenzie.”

As much as I wanted to believe the woman was joking, I started to realize that she probably wasn’t. The more I looked at her, the more I couldn’t shake the feeling that she looked familiar. She had the same smile as Mackenzie and even looked a little bit like my mom. “How could that possibly be true?” looking at her, I said, “Mackenzie is 7 years old; you look older than my parents.”

“Watch your mouth, young man.” A flash of anger appearing on her face, she said, “I’m only 34 years old.”

“Let’s say I believed what you’re saying; which I’m finding it really hard to do so, by the way.” Taking a breath, I said, “If you’re really my sister, then tell me something that only she would know about.”

“Okay fine; I’ll play your game.” Sighing, Mackenzie said, “When you were 11 years old, you were moving some boxes from your room to the attic. The bottom came out on one of them, and about a dozen issues of Playboy spilled out onto the hallway floor. You made me promise never to tell Mom and Dad.”

My eyes widened when I heard that; because it proved, without a doubt, that she was telling the truth. I had been moving boxes into the attic; one of which contained my stash of Playboys mixed in with some old books. The bottom gave out as I was walking past Mackenzie’s room. “Mac? Is that really you?”
11131.title: A Prank?

111311.content:
A smile formed on Mackenzie’s face as she looked at me. “Yeah, it’s really me.” Pulling me in for a hug, Mackenzie said, “I’ve missed you so much, Brian.”

It was already disturbing enough to find myself face to face with an adult version of my sister; I was more than a little uncomfortable with her hugging me. After breaking off the hug, I tried my best to hide the erection I suddenly found myself with. Looking at Mackenzie, I said, “How is it possible that 27 years have passed; while I haven’t aged at all?”

“I’m at a loss to explain that myself.” Sitting down in the chair next to me, Mackenzie said, “You look exactly the same as the last time I saw you.”

Before I could say anything, the door opened and I saw the little girl from earlier standing there. Looking from me to Mackenzie, she said, “Mommy, can I money for a juice?”

“Just a second, honey; there’s someone I want you to meet.” Walking over to the doorway, Mackenzie picked the girl up and came back over to the bed. Looking at me, she said, “Brian, I’d like you to meet your niece; Allison.”

I said hello to Allison but only got a blank stare from her. After getting money from Mackenzie, she left the room. Turning to Mackenzie, I said, “Only in this mixed-up situation would I have a niece who’s practically my age.”

“I’m afraid you’ve actually got two nieces and a nephew.” Chuckling, Mackenzie looked at me and said, “Allison’s my youngest, she’s 7; I also have a 9-year daughter named Megan and a 12-year-old son named Marcus.”

The deluge of information I was being given was too much for me to handle; I started crying. I’d missed so much of my sister’s life. Looking at her, I said, “I-I’m so sorry, Mac; I missed so much of your life.”

“You have nothing to apologize for, Brian; it wasn’t your fault.” Moving to the edge of the bed, Mackenzie held me close and kissed my forehead. “Who would have thought you’d disappear for 27 years.”

************************


Mackenzie and I remained in that position for a while; as I cried and she did her best to console me. The longer it went on for, the more it dawned on me that she was responding the way a mother would towards her child. After a while, she stepped out of the room to make a few phone calls; leaving me alone with my thoughts.

I had just walked out of the bathroom when Mac walked back into the room; still talking on her cell phone. “I don’t need a DNA test, honey; I just know this young man is my brother.” Sighing, she said, “I’m going to stay here for a while; Allison’s sleeping in one of the on-call rooms. Kiss the kids good night for me, alright? I love you.”

After Mackenzie hung up the phone, I looked at her and said, “Who was that on the phone?”

“That would be my husband, Duncan,” putting her phone away, Mackenzie said, “I think you’d like him; he’s a lot like Dad.”

It was at that point I realized, with everything going on, that I hadn’t thought about Mom and Dad. “How are Mom and Dad?” looking at her, I said, “Do they know I’m alive?”

“I tried to call Mom, but I got her voicemail.” Taking a deep breath, Mackenzie sat down and said, “Dad, unfortunately, died about a month after you disappeared.”
111311.title: A Family Reunion

1113111.content:
I couldn’t believe what I’d just heard. Struggling to hold back tears, I looked at Mac and said, “Dad...Dad’s dead?”

“He died a month after you disappeared.” Sitting next to me on the bed, Mac pulled me into an embrace. In a hushed voice, she looked at me and said, “He held on for as long as he could, but eventually it got to be too much for him.”

My dad was dead and I’d missed it. “I’m sorry Mac, t-that must’ve been hard for you.” Tears streaming down my face, I said, “I’m sorry I couldn’t have been there for you.”

“I’d be lying if I said that wouldn’t have made a difference.” Breaking the hug, Mac stood up and paced around for a second. Looking at me, she said, “I had a very rough childhood after that; I even started drinking in 6th grade.”

I was shocked. “Mac!?”

“I thought it was the only way I could get on with my life.” Sighing, I said, “I finally stopped after I got arrested for being at a high school senior’s party. I haven’t had a drink in 20 years.”

The two of us talked for a few more minutes until a nurse came into the room. “Mrs. Dawson, your daughter is asking for you.”

“Okay, I’ll be right there.” Looking at me, Mac said, “I won’t be long Brian.”

“I’ll be here when you get back.”

With a chuckle, Mac said, “You better be, mister.”

I sat there on the bed, with no one else in the room, for a few minutes; processing everything that I’d learned in the last few hours.
You’d think ending up 27 years in the future would be the most shocking thing to come from this; but, honestly, I was more shocked to learn that my little sister was a grown woman.

I eventually got bored so I decided to watch some TV; the problem was, I had no idea had to work the TV. I was about to call a nurse for help when I heard a ringing noise coming from Mac’s purse. I don’t know what compelled me to do so, but I decided to dig through Mac’s purse to see what the noise was coming from. I hope she won’t mind.

After a moment of searching, I came across what I could assume was a cell phone. I was about to set it aside when I noticed who was calling – Mom. Before I knew what I was doing, I answered the call. Suddenly an image of my mom, albeit older with grey hair and wrinkles, appeared on the screen.

We were both stunned for a moment; she was the first to finally speak. “Brian?”
1113111.title: Continue

11131111.content:
I found myself unable to say anything as I just stared at the image on the screen. The woman before me was certainly my mom; but she was older than I remembered, with wrinkles and a spattering of grey hair. I was still looking at her when she said, “Brian, is that you?”

“I-It’s me, Mom.”

“I can’t believe it; I thought your sister was playing some sort of cruel joke.” Looking at me, tears starting to well up, Mom said, “I spent 8 years looking for you; I hope you don’t think poorly of me for giving up.”

“Why would I think poorly of you for that?” with a chuckle, I said, “The odds that you’d find me after 8 years are so astronomically high.”

“I suppose the obvious thing to ask now; is where you were for 27 years?”

“That’s the thing, Mom; 27 years passed for everyone else, but for me, it was only a few hours.” Leaning back in the bed, I said,
“The last time I saw Mac, she was 7 years old; the next thing I know, she’s a grown woman with three kids.”

“Henry and I are on the first flight out tomorrow morning.” With a tearful smile, Mom said, “I never thought I’d get a chance to hold you in my arms again.”

Henry? Who's Henry? Wiping a tear from my face, I said, “I’ll see you tomorrow, Mom.”

“My little boy is back.”

Mom ended the call after that; I went to return Mac’s phone to her purse, just as she walked into the room. “What are you doing in my purse, Brian?”

“Your phone started ringing.” Looking at her, I said, “It was Mom.”

“Oh.” Any annoyance Mac had vanished instantly. Walking over, she said, “Did you talk to her?”

“Yeah, we talked.” Sighing, I looked at Mac and said, “Whose Henry?”
11131111.title: Talking With Mom

111311111.content:
Mac and I talked for a while after that; with her telling me about how Mom got remarried a couple of years after Dad died. Because my younger sister was now over 20 years older than me, I wasn’t entirely surprised to learn I had a 21-year-old half-brother.

“Aaron’s a great kid, I’m sure you two will get along swimmingly.” Looking at me, Mac said, “And Henry; well, he’s a great dad. He never tried to take Dad’s place in my heart, but he was still amazing in his way.”

“I can’t imagine, being a cop and all, that he was thrilled when you were arrested at that party.”

“Oh trust me, he wasn’t.” letting out a chuckle, Mac said, “I thought it was more because I embarrassed him with his coworkers; but in hindsight, I think he was upset that I felt I was alone.”

“You’ve told me all about what my friends have been up to.” Looking at Mac, I said, “I’d love to know what yours have been up to.”

“I didn’t have an easy time making, or even keeping, friends after you vanished.” Sighing, Mac said, “The only ones who stayed with me were Emily and Allison; this girl who moved to town a few weeks after you left.”

Allison and her twin brother Cameron, moved to town with their dad after their mom died. It was obvious what drew Allison and Mac together; I’m glad they were able to stay friends all these years. “So what’s Emily been up to?”

“She’s a pediatric surgeon at this hospital; she wanted to come to see you, but she got called in for emergency surgery.” Pausing, Mac said, “She’s got a daughter, Callie, that’s your age.”

“I imagine I’ll probably get to meet her at the get-together?”

“Absolutely.” Checking her watch, Mac said, “It’s getting late, you should probably get some rest. The nurses are letting Allison and I sleep in one of the on-call rooms; they’ll come to get me if you need anything.”

“Sounds good.” Smiling, I said, “Good night, Mac.”

“Good night, Brian.” Leaning over, Mac kissed me on the forehead and said, “I’m really happy you’re back.”
111311111.title: Continue

1113111111.content:
The first thing I noticed when I woke up the next morning was that I was still in the hospital; which meant I hadn’t disappeared again. The second thing I noticed was the perplexed face of Allison staring at me from the end of the bed.

“Hi, Allison.” Sitting up, I looked at her and said, “What can I do for you?”

“Mommy said you’re my uncle.” Staring at me, she said, “Is that true?”

“Yeah, it’s true.” With a little chuckle, I said, “Believe it or not, your mom is my younger sister.”

I could see the gears turning in Allison’s head while she processed what I’d just told her. After a minute, she said, “But mommy is older than you, how is that possible?”

“I’m not sure how to explain it, but I didn’t age while I was gone.” Wondering how to explain this, I said, “So although your mom is 34, I was born before her.”

Before Allison could question what I’d told her, Mac walked into the room with a tray of food. “Good morning, Brian.” Placing the tray on the table next to me, she said, “I’m glad you’re still here.”

“Believe me, I’m glad I am too.” Looking at her, I said, “Have you heard from Mom?”

“Yeah, I heard from her an hour ago. She and Henry are on a layover, they’ll be here in a few hours.”

Assuming the food was for me, I grabbed the tray and started eating. “Has Aaron said if he’s going to come by?” Looking at Mac,
I said, “I’d like to meet my brother at some point.”

“I talked to him last night after you went to bed.” Sighing, Mac said, “He’s on Spring Break in Miami, but he promises to call later on.”

“That sounds good.”

“I do have a surprise for you though.” With a smile, Mac said, “Are you up for some visitors?”

Very few people knew that I was back, but I’ll admit that I wondered who it could be. Looking at Mac, I nodded and said, “Sure, so long as they don’t mind me eating while they’re here.”

“Great, I’ll be right back.” Looking at Allison, Mac said, “Sweetie, why don’t you stay with your uncle.”

“Okay, Mommy.”

Mac walked out of the room; only to return a few minutes later with ______.
1113111111.title: The Next Morning

11131111111.content:
In stark contrast to when I first saw Mac, I immediately knew recognized the woman standing in the doorway. I think it had to do with the fact that I’d been blindsided by the sudden realization that Mac was a grown woman. But now that I had time to process everything, I was able to recognize minute details in people.

The woman’s smile, for instance, was a dead giveaway as to who she was. Looking at her, a smile of my own, I said, “Hey Emily, it’s been a while.”

“Oh my God!” coming over, Emily practically squeezed me to death as she hugged me. “Please tell me this isn’t some twisted practical joke.”

“It’s me, Em.” Catching my breath, I said, “You look good.”

The woman standing before me was most assuredly Emily, but I still had some difficulty believing it. I felt weird thinking this, since the last time I saw her she’d been 7 years old, but she’d grown into quite an attractive woman. Barely an inch taller than Mac, she could’ve easily passed for a woman in her mid-20s. “Oh please. I look like crap.” Chuckling, Emily said, “I spent the last 12 hours in surgery, I barely had time to take a shower.”

Suddenly Mac’s phone started ringing; after checking to see who it was, she said, “I’ll just be a minute. Em, can you keep an eye on Allison? She’s out here in the hall.”

“Sure thing.” Glancing at me, Emily said, “This’ll give me a chance to catch up with your brother.”

After Mac walked out of the room, I turned my attention back to Emily. “So what happened, I thought you wanted to be a teacher when you grew up.”

“I did; up until my junior year of High School.” Pulling up a chair, Emily said, “I took an AP anatomy class, and I just got hooked. So 11 years later, after racking up a considerable amount of debt, I became a board-certified pediatric surgeon.”


“I’m impressed; then again I always knew you were smart.” Leaning back in the bed, I said, “What else have you been up to? You married? Got any kids?”


“I have a 13-year-old daughter named Callie; I got pregnant a few months into my residency.” Taking a pause, Emily said, “As for being married; well, I haven’t found the right guy yet.”

“I’m sure he’s out there, don’t give up hope.” Chuckling, I said, “I kept forgetting to ask Mac about my friends; do you know what they’ve been up to?”

“They’re doing well; Collin and his wife, Andrea, have two kids. Carrie lives in Maryland with her wife and...”

“Wait a minute. Wife?”

“Oh right, you didn’t know” looking at me, Emily said, “Carrie came out about a year after you disappeared.”

“I never would’ve figured Carrie was a lesbian.” Chuckling, I said, “What about Eric? What’s he been up to?”

Emily went silent for a moment; which started to make me worried. After a moment, Emily said, “Eric is...well, he’s been through a lot.” Looking at me, she said, “So much so that I don’t think you’d recognized him.”

“What do you mean?”

“It’s not my place to say, Brian; that’s something you two need to discuss.”

I was worried; did something bad happen to Eric while I was gone? I didn’t have long to dwell on it, because suddenly a teenage girl walked into the room. “Hey Mom, Allison wants something to eat from the vending machine. Can I have a few bucks?”

“So long as it’s not anything too sugary.” Digging through her purse, Emily said, “Before you go, there’s someone I want you to meet.”

The girl, who I now realized was Emily’s daughter Callie, moved closer to her bed. Taking one look at me, she turned to Emily and said, “Is that him, Mom?”

“That’s right, sweetie; this is Aunt Mac’s brother.” Gesturing to me, Emily said, “Callie Rogers, meet Brian Hawkins.”
11131111111.title: Emily

111311111111.content:
From the moment the girl walked into the room, I knew there was something familiar about her. I did not fully realize what it was until Emily introduced her. Looking at her, I could immediately tell that Callie was Emily’s daughter.

Callie was the first to speak after the introduction; reaching her hand out, she said, “It’s nice to meet you, Brian.” Blushing a little bit, Callie said, “I’ve heard stories about you pretty much my entire life.”

“Really?” Turning to Emily, an eyebrow raised, I said, “People have been telling stories about me?

“To be fair, you did become famous after you vanished.” Smiling, Emily said, “Your disappearance became something of a mystery since they never found a body or a suspect.”

“Okay, I guess that’s fair.” Turning my attention back to Callie, I said, “So did I live up to all the hype?”

“Not exactly.” With a slight frown, Callie said, “I kind of thought you’d be taller.”

At 13 years old I was still only about 5’8,” so I shared Callie’s disappointment. “Believe me, so do I.”

At that moment, Mac appeared in the doorway and gestured for Emily to step out into the hall. “Callie, I’ll be right back; why don’t you stay and talk to Brian.”

“Sure thing, Mom; no problem.”

Once Emily left the room, I looked at Callie and said, “You don’t have to stay here if you don’t want to. It’s not like we know each other or anything.”

“I don’t mind staying here with you.” Chuckling, Callie said, “Besides, I’ve got nothing else to do this morning.”

**********************


I spent the next hour just talking with Callie; she did her best to bring me up to speed on everything I missed over the last 27 years. I reciprocated by telling her some stories about when her Mom was a kid; although I chose not to tell her anything embarrassing.

We also took the time to get to know each other a little better; as it turned out, Callie and I shared many of the same interests. She liked playing video games and going outdoors as much as I had. “Don’t get me wrong, though; I’ve got no problem showing off my feminine side if I need to.” With a grin, Callie said, “Just because I’m a girl doesn’t mean I don’t like getting down and dirty.”

“You’re your mother’s daughter, alright.” Chuckling, I looked at her and said, “You probably wouldn’t be surprised how many times they were mistaken for boys.”

“Oh I believe it; I saw some old photos of them when they were younger.” Smiling, Callie said, “I guess it runs in the family; when I
was younger I went through a phase where the only hairstyle I would want were buzz cuts. It made for some interesting conversations when Mom would bring me into the ladies’ room.”

As time went by, the two of us began talking like we were old friends. We were in the middle of talking about some TV show Callie thought I’d like when Mac and Emily walked into the room. “Okay Cal, I think we’ve taken up enough of Brian’s time.”

“If you say so, Mom.” Getting up, Callie looked at me and said, “It was nice meeting you, Brian; perhaps we can hang out once you get out of the hospital.”

“I’d like that; it’s just a question of when I’ll get out.”

After Callie and Emily left, Mac turned to me and said, “You two seemed to hit it off pretty easily.”

“Yeah, I guess.” Pausing, I said, “It helps that we have a lot of the same interests.”

“Once you’re out of here, I’ll give you her phone number.” Pausing, Mac said, “In the meantime, the doctors want to take you for an MRI.”

“An MRI?” suddenly worried, I said, “What for?”

“They noticed some peculiarities in the scans they took after you were brought in.” trying to sound comforting, Mac said, “Don’t worry, I’m sure it’s nothing.”

“Okay.” Still worried, I said, “Have you heard from Mom?”

“Not since they boarded the plane; don’t worry, they’ll be here soon.”
111311111111.title: Talking with Callie

1113111111111.content:
A nurse soon entered the room and brought me down to the radiology department; with Mac following close behind. As we got out of the elevator, I turned to her and said, “Mac, you don’t need to stay with me 24/7; you have your own family to take care of.”

“Don’t be foolish Brian; you’re my family too.” Placing a hand on my shoulder, Mac said, “Forgive me for not wanting to let you out of my sight.”

I guess I couldn’t blame her from wanting to be close by; especially since I’d been missing for the last 27 years. If I were in her position I’d likely be doing the same thing.

I sat quietly in the wheelchair as the nurse turned down a hallway leading to the MRI. No one had said anything for a few moments, so I decided to break the ice. “I suppose you must’ve heard a lot about me?”

Shaking her head, the nurse said, “No, not really.”

“Really?” I was surprised to hear that. “I thought it was a big story back then?”

“It probably was, but I was a little girl then.” Looking down at me, the nurse said, “If it didn’t happen on Disney Junior, I didn’t know about it.”

Hearing that just made me realize, even more, how much everything had changed. My little sister was now a grown woman and my nurse couldn’t have been older than 4 years old when I disappeared. It made me wonder how many other hospital staff had been kids when I disappeared.

The three of us rounded a corner heading towards the MRI; the nurse was about to wheel me in when a doctor stopped us at the door. Looking at Mac, he said, “I’m sorry ma’am, but only patients and medical staff are allowed past this point.”

“That’s my brother, doctor.” Getting defensive, Mac said, “I’m not letting him out of my sight.”

The doctor wasn’t having any of it; he looked as though he was going to call security when the nurse stepped in. “Doctor Amherst, this is the boy who disappeared 27 years ago.”

The doctor looked from me to Mac for a moment. With a sigh, he said, “Okay fine, but don’t touch anything and stay out of my way.”
1113111111111.title: The MRI

11131111111111.content:
The 45 minutes that I spent inside the MRI were the most uncomfortable in recent memory; due in large part to my claustrophobia. If it hadn’t been for Mac helping to keep me calm over the intercom, I doubt I would’ve made it through.

Once the MRI was finished, the nurse brought Mac and me back to my hospital room. I went to lie in bed while Mac went to get me a glass of water. She returned a few minutes later with both a pitcher of water and some cups. I helped myself to one of the cups and poured some water. After taking a quick sip, I turned to look at Mac. “Thanks for keeping me calm during the MRI, Mac.”

Sitting on the edge of the bed, Mac placed a hand on my shoulder. “You’re welcome, sweetie.” Gently starting to rub my back, she said, “I remember how much you hated tight spaces.”

It didn’t even faze me that Mac had called me sweetie; the only thing I could think about was how comforting it was for her to be here. I leaned over and rested my head on her shoulder. “You always did have a knack for keeping me calm.” Looking up at her, I said, “I’m glad you didn’t lose that over the years.”

“If anything being a mother has helped me hone that ability.” looking down at me, Mac said, “Megan was terrified of thunderstorms when she was younger; I found that I was the only one who could keep her calm.”

“Well, I’m glad that’s the case.” Smiling, I said, “I needed that more than ever today.”

Mac and I remained as we were for a while; the whole time I couldn’t help but notice how easily she went into mom-mode around me.
11131111111111.title: Post-MRI

111311111111111.content:
We ended up only having to wait about 30 minutes before the doctor came in with what I could only assume were my MRI results, along with what looked like a very old file. As he closed the door, feeling anxious, I said, “What did you find in the MRI, doctor?”

“Do you remember an incident when you were 11 years old?” looking at me, he said, “You were brought into the ER after a zip line accident.”

I remembered that incident vividly; it was Collin’s birthday and we all went to this adventure park on the outside of town. I must not have been secured properly, because about halfway through my ride the harness snapped and I felt twenty feet to the ground. “Yeah, it’s pretty hard to forget something like that.” Rubbing my head, I said, “I fractured my skull in two places and broke both my legs.”

“I’m sorry doctor, but I’m confused.” Placing a hand on my shoulder, Mac said, “What does an accident from 30 years ago have to do with what’s going on?”

“As you may recall, Mrs. Douglas; once we realized who your brother was, we had to search through decades-old files to find his charts.” Digging through the file, the doctor placed an x-ray image on a nearby display. “This was from the day your brother was brought in; you can see the fractures on his skull.”

Mac and I both looked at the image on the display; sure enough, we could both see the fractures. “I feel as though you’re about to tell us something.” Turning back to the doctor, I said, “Stop beating around the bush and get it over with.”

The doctor silently pulled out another x-ray image and placed it on the display. “This image was taken last night after you were brought in, Brian.” Pointing at the image, he said, “I’m at a loss to explain this; but your skull fractures seem to have vanished.”

“What?” looking at the image, I said, “That’s impossible.”

“That’s what I kept telling myself, but the evidence is as clear as day.” Looking at me, the doctor said, “What’s more is that there’s no longer any evidence of the TBI you sustained during the fall.”

That TBI had thrown all my plans for summer vacation out the window; the youth football league wouldn’t let me play with an injury like that. “I'm an accountant, so you'll have to forgive my ignorance." looking back at the doctor, Mac said, "What exactly are you saying, doctor?”

“What I’m saying, Mrs. Douglas, is that your brother is in perfect health.” Gesturing to my chart, he said, “In fact, all of his tests show that he’s healthier than he was 27 years ago.”

Mac and I exchanged confused looks with each other; neither of us had any idea what was going on. But before I could ask the doctor for an explanation, the door opened and Mom barged into the room.
111311111111111.title: The Results

1113111111111111.content:
Even though I’d already seen her on the phone, I was still taken aback by how old Mom looked. She had a few more wrinkles than the video call showed, and her hair wasn’t as grey as I thought, but I was still able to recognize that it was her.

Suddenly overcome with emotion I climbed out of bed and, before anyone could stop me, I ran across the room to Mom. I came close to making her fall over as I hugged her; as I instantly started crying. I still wasn’t sure what was going on, but I knew everything was going to be alright now that my mom was here.

After letting me cry for a moment, Mom gently extricated herself from my grip and looked at me. “I can’t believe it’s you, Brian.” Touching my face, she said, “The entire flight here all I kept thinking about was that this was some cruel trick.”

“That was my first thought too, Mom.” Walking up behind us, Mac said, “But all the tests say that this is, in fact, Brian.”

Mom embraced me once again, saying, “Do you have any clue about what happened to you?”

“I’m afraid not, Mom; the last thing I remembered before waking up here was playing hide and seek in the woods with Mac.”

“There’s another facet to this mystery that we just found out, Mom.” Standing next to me, Mac said, “It seems that Brian’s zip line injury has miraculously healed itself; there’s no sign of his skull fracture or his TBI.”

“I suppose there’s no point in asking how something like is even possible.” Holding me close, Mom looked at Mac and said, “Have you been in contact with Brian’s friends?”

“Emily stopped by earlier; I spoke with Carrie and Collin last night, they said they’ll be here later this afternoon.” Gesturing to me, Mac said, “He was asking about Eric, but I didn’t think it was my place to tell him.”

“I begged her to tell me, but she wouldn’t.” Glancing up at Mom, I said, “What’s going on with Eric, Mom? I deserve to know what’s going on with my best friend.”

“Of course you do, Brian.” Sighing, Mom said, “But your sister’s right; it’s not our place to tell you.”

“Fine, I’ll just ask him when he gets here.”

Breaking away from mom, I went back to the bed just as an older man walked into the room. I was about to ask who he was when he kissed Mom and said, “I finally found a spot on Level 4.”

“I’m guessing you’re Henry?”

“That’s right.” Walking over to me, Henry said, “I must say, it’s a pleasure to finally meet you, Brian. Yours was one of the toughest cases of my entire career.”

Raising an eyebrow, I said, “What’s that supposed to mean?”

“I’m a retired detective.” Pausing, Henry said, “I was part of the team looking for you.”
1113111111111111.title: Reunited with Mom

11131111111111111.content:
Despite my protests to the contrary, Mom and Mac left the room to give Henry and me a chance to talk. It wasn’t that I didn’t want to talk with him; it was just that I didn’t even know him.

The two of us sat in silence for what felt like an eternity before Henry finally said something. “I imagine all of this must-have come as a surprise to you, huh?”

“Wow, that’s very perceptive of you.” Sighing, I said, “Did your detective skills tell you that?”

I instantly came to regret what I said; when I saw the pained look on Henry’s face. “I suppose that was a pretty stupid question to ask.”

“I didn’t mean for it to come out like that.” Looking at him, I said, “It’s just, I only just met you. I don’t know why Mac and Mom thought this was a good idea.”

“Yeah, I don’t understand it either.” Taking a breath, Henry said, “But we might as well make the best of it. Do you have any questions you want to ask me?”

I sat in silence for a moment while I thought about a long list of questions that I wanted answers to. After a moment, I settled on one in particular and said, “How’d you go from being one of the detectives on my case to being married to my mom?”

“We became friendly early on; offering each other emotional support.” Looking at me, Henry said, “You see, I was going through a pretty nasty divorce at the time. Your mom helped me with that; while I helped her cope with your disappearance and your father’s declining health.”

“Forgive me for asking this; but did you two become involved while my dad was still alive?”

“No, we didn’t become involved until about a year after your father died.” Looking at me, he said, “But that doesn’t mean I wasn’t in the picture. I helped out with the housework and even helped Mackenzie with her problems.”

“Mac mentioned she had a drinking problem when she was younger.” Taking a pause, I said, “How bad did it get for her?”

“I wouldn’t wish what your sister went through on anyone; not even my worst enemy. Losing both her brother and her father in a month took its toll on her.” Sighing, Henry said, “She was suspended from school several times for fighting; she got in trouble for stealing a bottle of soda from a gas station. We didn’t find out about the drinking until she got arrested at a party a few blocks away.”

I’d known about the drinking but the rest was all a big surprise. I had a hard time believing that the person Henry was describing was my sister. Looking at Henry, I said, “How did she finally work past all that?”

“She got through it with some help from your mom, me, and her friends.” Pausing, Henry said, “She resisted at first, but finally came around after your brother was born.”

“Mac didn’t tell me a whole lot about Aaron; only that he’s on Spring Break right now.” Looking at Henry, I said, “What’s he like?”

“He’s a great kid; smart as a fox.” Smiling, Henry said, “I’m sure you’ll like him; you both have similar interests.”

“I guess I’ll just have to work past the fact that I was born before my older brother.”

Chuckling, Henry said, “Give it some time, I’m sure you’ll get used to it.”

Mac came walking into the room at that moment. "I'm sorry to interrupt, but there's someone outside who wants to speak with Brian."

"Okay." looking at Mac, I said, "Send them in."

Mac leaned out the door and waved at someone I couldn't see. I watched as a woman, in her early 40s and wearing a business suit, walked into the room. With everything going on, I figured she must've been from Social Services or something. But I couldn't shake the feeling that she looked familiar. Whoever she was, I watched as Henry stood up and made his way towards the door.

Mac and Henry left the room; leaving me alone with the woman. Looking at me, she said, "I couldn't believe it when Mac told me you were back."

"I'm sorry, but who are you?"

"I imagine I look very different from the last time you saw me." stepping closer to the bed, the woman said, "My name is Andrea, but you knew me as Eric."
11131111111111111.title: Meeting Henry

111311111111111111.content:
I stared at the woman in disbelief; there was no way she could have been Eric. For one thing, she was a woman. The silence in the room was deafening; as we both just stared at each other.

After a moment I finally got up the nerve to speak. “Forgive me, but there’s no way you’re Eric.” Looking at her, I said, “I mean you’re a woman, and Eric was a guy.”

“I was never a guy, Brian; it just took me a while to finally become who I was supposed to be.” Sighing, Andrea said, “There has to be something I could do to prove I’m telling the truth.”

“If you’re Eric, then tell me something that only he would know.”

Andrea pulled up a chair next to my bed; she sat down and looked at me. “When they brought you into the ER after your zip lining incident; the nurse asked you how many fingers she was holding up.” Pausing, she said, “She was holding up 6, but you said ‘Spider-man.’”

If I had been drinking any water, I probably would’ve done a spit take. As impossible as it seemed, the woman sitting before me was my best friend. “It’s really you, Eric?”

“Please call me Andrea; I haven’t gone by Eric in almost 30 years.”

I went silent again as I tried to process everything. Andrea was an attractive woman; a little on the tall side for a woman but with a nice figure. The more I looked at her though, the more I was able to see hints of my friend in her face. “I thought Mom and Mac had changed since I saw them last, but you…” pausing, I said, “When did all of this happen?”

“Do you remember, the day you disappeared, when I called you on the phone? I told you I had something important to talk with you about.” Gesturing to herself, Andrea said, “Well, this was it. I went to my aunt’s house to start my transition in secret; you were the first one I was going to tell.”

“Forgive me if I’m being awkward, but you look amazing.”

“Thanks, I go to the gym three times a week.” Leaning closer, Andrea said, “Just between you and me; it’s nice to know I’m still considered attractive at my age. My kid’s friends are always complimenting me about how I look.”

“You have kids?” confused, I said, “Did they make some medical breakthroughs while I was gone?”

“Sadly no, a woman like me is still unable to get pregnant.” Pausing, Andrea said, “I did things the old fashion way; Emily donated some eggs while Grace carried them to term.”

“I’m sure you’re an excellent mother.”

“I like to think so, but there are times when my kids think I’m terrible.” Chuckling, she said, “Thankfully Collin is there to help clear things up.”

"I have to admit, I'm a little surprised to hear that you married Collin."

“We just celebrated our 19th-anniversary last month. I don’t blame you for being surprised by that; after all, I had a crush on someone else until he disappeared on me.”

It took longer than I wanted to admit before I realized she was talking about me. “You had a crush on me?”

“I had a huge crush on you since the 7th grade, but I never said anything because I knew you wouldn’t feel the same way.” Blushing a little bit, Andrea said, “After I started my transition, I dreamed of the day when I could be your girlfriend. But then you disappeared, and I eventually started dating Collin.”

“For what it’s worth, I’m sorry you never got to be my girlfriend.” Looking at her, I said, “I trust that Collin and you are happy?”

“He’s the love of my life and the father of my children.” Pausing, Andrea said, “I wouldn’t trade him for anyone else in the world.”

The two of us talked for a few more minutes about married life and Andrea’s kids. It seemed that Andrea was truly happy with her life; and I, in turn, was happy for her. “So what do you do for a living?”

“I’m in charge of the Woman’s Fashion department at Bloomingdales.” Smiling, Andrea continued, “It’s my dream job; even if I have a 90-minute commute each way.”

“Wait a minute; its 10:00 on a Wednesday, why aren’t you at work?”

“I had a doctor’s appointment; one, I might add, that I’ve had to reschedule three times.” Pausing, Andrea said, “I figured I’d kill two birds with one stone; go to the appointment and then stop by to see you before going to work.”

“Well, in that case, I won’t keep you any longer.” Smiling, I said, “It’s great to see you again, Andrea.”

“It’s great to see you again, Brain.” Hugging me, Andrea said, “I never thought this day would come.”
111311111111111111.title: A Shocking Reunion

1113111111111111111.content:
It had been about 15 minutes since Andrea left, and I’d been alone since then. I was still trying to wrap my head around everything I’d learned; my best friend had become a woman and was married to another of my friends. Not only that, but she had two kids that were only a few years older than me.

I was sitting in bed when Mac entered the room. “Now you understand why Mom and I couldn’t tell you what happened to Eric.” Looking at me, she said, “It wouldn’t have been appropriate for anyone but Andrea to tell you.”

“I’m sorry for pestering you guys about it so much.” Sitting up in bed, I said, “I’m still trying to get a grasp on all of it; growing up, I had no idea that she was trans.”

“You mean to tell me that you had no idea?” sitting in the chair next to the bed, Mac said, “Andrea was your best friend; if anyone should’ve noticed something it was you.”

I looked back on my memories of spending time with Andrea. The more I thought about it, the more I realized that I had noticed some inexplicable incidents when we were kids. “Now that you mention it, I did remember catching her wearing Grace’s cheerleading outfit one time.” Pausing, I said, “I did always find it weird that she always dressed as female characters for Halloween.”

“I assume that she told you about her crush?”

“Yeah, we talked about that for a few minutes.” Smiling, I said, “I’m glad she ended up with Collin; after all, relationships at that age rarely last.”

“She never forgot about you, Brian; you always had a special place in her heart.” Tearing up a little, Mac said, “I don’t know if she told you this, but she named her son after you.”

Now it was my turn to tear up; learning the impact I had on my best friend’s life even after I disappeared. “She didn’t say anything about that, but she did say that I would meet them at the party.”

There was suddenly a knock at the door, followed by mom poking her head inside. “They’re here, Mackenzie.”

“Okay, thanks, Mom.”

Looking at Mac, I said, “Who’s here?”

“I don’t want this to seem like a revolving door of visitors, but there are some people I’d like for you to meet.” Mac stood up as a man appeared in the doorway with a boy and a girl. Looking at me, Mac said, “You already met Allison; so it’s only fair to meet the rest of my family.”
1113111111111111111.title: Talking with Mac

11131111111111111111.content:
I spent almost 30 minutes talking with the rest of Mac’s family; her husband Duncan, her oldest daughter Megan and her son Marcus. While Duncan and Megan were willing to talk with me, I could tell that Marcus was less than enthusiastic. I guess I couldn’t blame him since I was the same way at that age.

Duncan, as it turned out, is a history teacher at the High School; Megan did gymnastics on the weekend and Marcus was on the peewee football team. After a while Megan and Marcus left the room, leaving me alone with Duncan and Mac. Turning his attention to me, Duncan said, “So Brian, did your sister discuss your living arrangements after you get out of the hospital?”

“Not really, but I figured it was only a matter of time before Mom told me.” Shrugging, I said, “It’ll be weird moving away from here, but I think I’ll like it in Florida.”

Duncan and Mac exchanged curious glances with each other until Mac turned back to me. “Brian, sweetie, I think there’s been a misunderstanding.” Sighing, she said, “You’re going to be staying here with us.”

That wasn’t at all what I had been expecting. “What?” in shock, I said, “There’s no way I’m living with you guys.”

“I’m afraid that’s your only option unless you want to go into foster care.” Looking at me, Mac said, “The retirement village where Mom and Dad live won't allow anyone under the age of 55 to live there.”

There was so much about that sentence I wanted to discuss; chief being that Mac had referred to Henry as Dad. But I decided to focus on the fact that I was being forced to live with Mac and her family. “There’s no way you’ll be allowed to let me live with you.” Scoffing, I said, “You’re my little sister for Christ’s sake.”

“In case you haven’t noticed, Brian; I’m a 34-year-old woman and you’re only 13 years old.” Getting frustrated, Mac said, “You may not like it, but I’m well within my legal rights to become your legal guardian.”

“I’d live with Aaron before I lived with you.”

Mac rolled her eyes out of sheer frustration “God, I forgot how stubborn you could be. Listen to me, young man; Aaron doesn’t even know who you are. Do you think he’d let a 13-year-old boy live with him? For all you know, he’s living in some bachelor apartment.” Stepping closer to me, raising her voice, Mac said, “You may not want to hear this, but I know more about how these things work than you do. Maybe, somewhere down the line, we can discuss this some more; but for time being you have to listen to what I say.”

I recoiled slightly as Mac got closer to me; taken aback by the sudden change in her tone. It brought back memories of when Mom would use the same tone with me as a kid. I certainly didn’t like it; but Mac was right, I had to accept that she was the adult and I was the kid.
11131111111111111111.title: Continue

111311111111111111111.content:
I was left alone for a little while after my fight with Mac; Duncan had convinced her to give me some time to process everything. And boy did I have a lot to process; rather than live with my Mom like I thought I would, I was stuck living with my sister.

After almost 45 minutes of that, I was starting to get bored when there was a knock at the door. “Come in.”

The door opened and two people walked into the room. Despite having aged almost 30 years since I last saw them, I knew immediately that Collin and Carrie had walked into the room. Carrie looked pretty much the same except her hair was now a short buzz cut; Collin, on the other hand, looked as if he lost a considerable amount of weight since I last saw them.

To their credit, they had the same surprised looks on their faces that everyone else had. Carrie was the first to do anything, as she came over and hugged me. “I couldn’t believe it when your sister said you were alive.” Looking at me, she said, “But how are you the same age you were when you disappeared?”

“I’ll stop you right there, Carrie; I have no idea why I haven’t aged at all.” Sighing, I said, “Everyone’s been asking me that same question and I’m, honestly, getting sick of it.”

“That’s understandable.” Smiling, she said, “Regardless, I’m thrilled to have you back.”

“Me too, buddy.” Walking over, Collin shook my hand and said, “I can’t say I ever expected to see you again.”

“It’s good to be back, man.”

************************


After all the basics were taken care of, the three of us spent the next hour or so talking. Carrie showed me pictures of her wife and daughter; while Collin showed me pictures of his and Andrea’s kids. Brian, my namesake, was a spitting image of Collin; while I could a little bit of Emily in his daughter Grace.

“I feel terrible that I wasn’t there for Andrea during her transition, but I’m glad you guys were there for her.” Turning to Collin, I said, “I was surprised to hear that you guys got married.”

“I initially had no interest in dating her; but then one day she walked into school looking incredible.” With a smile on his face, Collin said,
“Suddenly I wanted nothing more than to be her boyfriend; and the rest, as they say, is history.”

“I imagine your folks needed time to adjust to something like that.”

“Not as much as you’d think.” Chuckling, Carrie said, “I’d come out by that point and was already dating; they figured that if they supported me, then they’d have to support Collin.”

“I can’t believe I missed so much your guy’s lives. We all had big plans for our futures.” Tearing up, I said, “You guys got to grow up and start families; while I’m still stuck as a kid.”

“You’ll get there eventually, Brian.” Coming over to console me, Carrie said, “Someday you’ll have a wife and kids of your own.”

“Yeah, kiddo; don’t be in such a rush to grow up.” looking at me, trying to be reassuring, Collin said, “Like I tell my kids, enjoy this time while you can.”
111311111111111111111.title: Carrie & Collin Visit

1113111111111111111111.content:
It had been a few hours since Carrie and Collin left, and I’d been alone pretty much since they left. To be honest, I was starting to get a little stir crazy; I wanted to leave the hospital. Considering my past experiences with hospitals, you can understand why I didn’t like them very much; what with my injury and my dad’s cancer diagnosis.

I was flipping through the channels on TV; noting, with annoyance, that some of my favorite shows were now considered classics. I had just started watching an episode of Grey’s Anatomy when Mac walked to the room; phone in hand. Seeing me, she said, “Hey Brian; I was thinking of calling Aaron, you want to talk to him?”

“I don’t see why not; sure beats watching TV.” Sitting up, I said, “Besides, he’s my younger brother after all.”

Mac let out a little chuckle after I said that; before catching herself and said, “Sorry, it’s just that’s funny; since technically you’re
his younger brother.”

“Yeah, but I was born before...you know what, let’s not get into that right now.” Moving over so Mac could sit down, I said, “I must admit I’m a little nervous; what if he doesn’t like me?”

“You’re brothers; why wouldn’t he like you.” Dialing Aaron’s number, Mac turned the screen towards me. “He may be out with his
girlfriend, so I’m not sure he’ll...”

As if on cue, the dial screen was replaced with the face of a young man with brown hair. “Hey sis, what’s up?”

“If you’ve got some time, I was thinking you’d like to meet Brian.”

“Well Becky and I are leaving for dinner shortly; but I suppose I could meet him.”

Angling the phone towards me, Mac said, “Brian, meet your brother Aaron; Aaron, meet your brother Brian.”

The two of us just stared at each other for a few seconds; neither of us quite knowing what to say. There was no way to tell over the phone, but I suspected that he was quite tall. He was pretty muscular and had brown hair; from what I could tell he looked like a younger version of Henry.

Aaron was the first one of us to speak. “So you’re my older brother, huh?”

“I guess you could say that; I mean you are physically older than me, even if I was born first.”

“It doesn’t matter in the long run; so long as we know we’re brothers.” Looking closer at the screen, Aaron said, “I can see a little of Mom in you, but I’m guessing you mostly took after your dad.”

“Yeah, there are pictures of my dad when he was my age; I looked almost identical to him.” Getting a little emotional, talking about my dad, I decided to change the subject. “So what was it like, growing up and hearing stories about me?”

“I’ll be honest, Brian; it wasn’t easy.” Sighing, Aaron said, “Because of what happened to you Mom and Dad were very protective of me; to the point where it got excessive.”

I caught sight of a naked girl, who I assumed was Aaron’s girlfriend, scurry past in the background. Turning my attention back to Aaron, I said, “I’m sorry about that.”

“Hey man, don’t apologize; it’s not your fault.” Chuckling, Aaron said, “If it makes you feel better, Mackenzie and Mom told me nothing but good stories about you.”

Raising an inquisitive eyebrow, I glanced at Mac as I said, “Oh really?”

“Yeah; they even showed me that photo of you wearing Mackenzie’s ballet outfit.”

When Mackenzie was 6 years old, my parents had convinced her to try something girly; so she signed up for ballet. She only lasted for a few months before quitting out of sheer boredom; but by that point we’d gotten Dad’s prognosis so the ballet school was sympathetic. Blushing, I said, “I’ll have you know, I only did that on a dare.”

That got a chuckle out of Mac; while Aaron responded, “If you say so, man; you seemed to know the moves pretty well.”

Choosing to ignore that comment, I said, “I have to remember to delete that video.”

Just then the girl from earlier, now wearing a rather elegant dress, came up next to Aaron. “Aaron, honey, we’ve got to go or we’ll miss our reservation.”

“Sorry Beck, I’m just talking with my brother.”

There was a confused look on Becky’s face; but it quickly disappeared. Looking at the screen, she said, “So you’re Aaron’s brother, the one who disappeared?”

“That’s me.”

“I have to say; Aaron was quite surprised when he heard you suddenly reappeared.” Pausing, Becky said, “All this must be so strange for you; hell, I hadn’t even been born yet when you disappeared.”

“It’s been an adjustment; but I’m getting through it with help from my mom and sister.” Smiling, I said, “I won’t keep you guys any longer; I hope you have a nice dinner.”

“I hope so, too.” Chuckling, Becky said, “After all, it’s our 2nd anniversary.”

I saw Aaron in the background putting on a suit jacket. Turning back towards the camera, he said, “I’ll see you at the party this weekend, Brian. I can’t wait to meet you in person.”

After hanging up the call, I returned the phone to Mac and said, “He seems like a nice guy.”

“He’s a great guy; I think you two will get along great.” Leaning closer, in a whisper, Mac said, “Just between you and me; Aaron said he’s going to propose to Becky tonight. If all goes well, you’ll get a brother and a sister-in-law.”

“Aaron mentioned the party this weekend.” Taking a breath, I said, “Am I going to be out of the hospital by then?”

“I forgot to mention; unless something changes, the doctors say you’ll be free to go tomorrow.”
1113111111111111111111.title: Later On (Meeting Aaron)

11131111111111111111111.content:
Having spent the last few days in the hospital, I couldn’t have been more excited to leave. I had ended up almost 30 years in the future and, aside from seeing changes at the hospital, I hadn’t really seen anything futuristic.

Except for Mac and Duncan, the only other people there to see me off were Mom, Henry, and Emily. It was incredibly cheesy, but Mac couldn’t resist recording me leave the hospital.

After saying goodbye to Emily, who had to go back to work, I followed Mac and Duncan through the parking lot to their car. The first time I saw it, all I could picture were the cars from that Will Smith movie I, Robot. The car looked almost identical to the ones in the movie.

I climbed into the back seat while Mac and Duncan got in the front. Given how far in the future we were, I suppose I shouldn’t have been surprised when all Duncan had to do was press a button and say “Home.” The car immediately started driving on its own, while Mac and Duncan’s chairs spun around to face me.

As a small table came up out of the floor, Mac looked at me and said, “Duncan and I discussed it with Brian this morning; he’s not too thrilled about it, but you two will be roommates.”

It took until last night for Mac to tell me that her family was living in the house I grew up in. While I was excited to see what it looked like after close to 30 years, I was a little surprised to hear that Mac and Duncan hadn’t made many changes to it. Sleeping space was still at a premium; so while the girls shared a room, Brian had a room to himself. At least he did until I came along.

My first introduction to my nephew hadn’t been the best; in fact, I was pretty sure he disliked me for some reason. I could only hope that sharing a room would fix that. Looking at Mac, I said, “Not that it matters; but is it my old room or your old room?”

“Don’t worry; it’s your old room.” pausing, Mac said, “Just so there are no surprises we did make some changes, like repaint the walls, but it’s still largely the same as it was 27 years ago.”
11131111111111111111111.title: Leaving the Hospital

choices: Later On (Hanging with Allison, Megan and Marcus)
111311111111111111111111.content:
Mac and Duncan weren’t kidding when they said the house was pretty much unchanged after 27 years. Sure there were some cosmetic changes; the outside was a different color and there was no a roof over the front porch, but other than that was still the house I grew up in.

As the car pulled into the driveway, I saw Allison, Megan, and Marcus standing outside; each of them holding onto a large sign that said – Welcome Home Brian!! A thought came to mind as I saw that sign; so, turning to Mac, I said, “Perhaps you guys should explain to me how I’m going to get my life back.” Pausing, I said, “I’ve been legally dead for 27 years; so I assume that’s no easy task.”

“We’ve got an appointment at the courthouse tomorrow morning; to get all that settled.” Sighing, as she got out of the car, Mac said, “Once you’re legally alive again, I’ll file the paperwork to become your legal guardian, and then we’ll look into getting you back into school.”

I don’t know what disturbed me more; the fact that my sister was going to be my legal guardian or the idea that I’d be going to school with people whose parents were in 2nd grade 27 years ago. Getting out of the car, following after Mac and Duncan, I said,

“Do I need a legal guardian?” pausing, I said, “After all, I’m technically 40 years old right now.”

Mac chuckled a bit at that remark. “I’m sorry, Brian; but I’m afraid that’s not how it works.” Turning around to look at me, Mac said, “Chronologically you’re 40 years old; but in terms of your physical age, you’re only 13.”

“Think about it this way, Mac; you and Duncan will effectively be my parents.” Stopping in the driveway, I said, “Is that something you’re okay with?”

“If I wasn’t okay with it, I wouldn’t have suggested it.” Getting flustered, Mac said, “Now come on; let’s go inside.”
111311111111111111111111.title: Coming Home

1113111111111111111111111.content:
Once everyone went off to do their own thing, I took the opportunity to look around the house to see how much of it was as I remembered. It was pretty much as I’d expected; after all, Mac had said they didn’t change much.

But that didn’t mean nothing had changed; the carpeting in the house was already pretty old when I disappeared, so I wasn’t surprised to find that had been replaced at some point. The kitchen was where the most changes had occurred; there was a kitchen island with a stove built into it, and there was now a large bay window overlooking the backyard.

I was staring out the window, happy to see that my old treehouse was still there when I heard footsteps behind me. Turning around, I saw Megan walking into the kitchen. It looked as though she was going for the fridge but at the last minute she changed her mind and walked towards me. “I can’t even imagine how weird this all must be for you.” Chuckling, she said, “To you, only a few days have passed; so to see all these changes must be weird.”

“Weird doesn’t even begin to describe how all this feels.” Sighing, I said, “One minute I’m playing hide and seek with my sister; the next minute she’s 34 years old and has three children.”

“If you ever need help with anything, you can always ask me.”

“Now that you mention it, I could use your advice on something,” turning to look at Megan, I said, “Marcus doesn’t seem to like me very much.”

“That’s just Marcus; it takes him time to come around to new people.” Taking a breath, Megan said, “My advice is to give him space, he’ll come around soon enough.”

“Forgive me for asking this, but how do you feel about me?”

“Everything I know about you comes from my mom’s stories.” Turning to me, Megan took a breath and said, “I only just met you
yesterday; but from what I can tell, you seem like a nice guy.”

“I suppose I can live with that.”

Duncan came walking into the room at that point; looking towards me, he said, “Brian why don’t you go upstairs and check out your sleeping arrangements.” Pausing, Duncan said, “I’d tell you where to go, but it used to be your bedroom.”

“Sounds good.” Turning to Megan, I said, “Thanks for the talk, Megan.”

“Anytime, Brian.”
1113111111111111111111111.title: Checking Out the House

11131111111111111111111111.content:
Although only a few days had passed for me; in actuality, more than 27 years since I’d entered my bedroom. As I stood in the doorway, I was surprised to see that it didn’t look all that different. I mean; yeah, the stuff inside the room wasn’t the same as 27 years ago. But I could still tell that it was a teenage boy’s bedroom.

I honestly wouldn’t be surprised if I learned that Marcus had some Playboys hidden in the air vent under the bed. Walking into the room, I examined the plethora of posters on the wall as well as what I could only imagine was a video game console underneath a large TV.

Walking over to the TV, I was about to check out the console when I heard a noise behind me. Turning around, I saw Marcus staring at me with an annoyed look in his eyes. “You know, typically someone asks before just walk into someone’s bedroom.”

“Sorry about that.” Watching Marcus as he walked into the room, I said, “It’s just; this used to be my room.”

“Yeah, it used to be your room; now it’s mine.” Walking past me, Marcus said, “Look; I’m not exactly thrilled about having a roommate, so my advice to you is not to piss me off.”

By now Marcus’ attitude was starting to get on my nerves; so I decided to confront him about it. “I don’t know why you’re so angry with me, Marcus; it’s not like I asked for any of this,” approaching him, I said, “But regardless; I’m here now, so you better get used to it.”

“Is there a problem here?”

Marcus and I turned to find Mac standing in the doorway; a stern expression on her face. “It’s nothing, Mom; Brian just came in here without asking.”

“He doesn’t need permission, Marcus; you’ll both be sharing this room.” walking into the room, Mac said, “Besides; this was his bedroom long before it was yours.”

“I just don’t understand he has to stay here with us.”

“Marcus Douglas, I can’t believe you’d say such a thing.” Astonished, Mac said, “He’s my brother; what did you expect me to do?”

“I’m your son, Mom.” Desperately trying to plead his case, Marcus said, “I think I deserve a little courtesy; perhaps ask me if I’d be okay with this instead of forcing it on me.”

I found myself agreeing with Marcus on that point; Mac hadn’t bothered to ask either of us if we were okay with this. She was forcing us into a situation neither Marcus nor myself wanted to be in. “I agree with Marcus, Mac; I think you should’ve given us the courtesy of talking this over.” Sighing, I said, “After all, I changed your diapers; this is the least you could do.”

Mac stared at the two of us; trying to figure out her response. “Let’s forget for a moment that I’m an adult and you’re both children. Where exactly would I find the space for both of you to have a private room?” seeing the looks on our faces, Mac said, “That’s right; I considered the possibility for a brief time. But then I realized that not only would it not be fair to Megan and Allison; but it might force you two to grow up.”

Marcus started stammering, as I looked at Mac. “That’s funny, coming from you; after all, I seem to recall you have a hissy fit at the mall because Mom wouldn’t let you buy a doll you wanted.” Taking a breath, I said, “So the next time you tell us that we need to grow up; why don’t you look in the mirror.”

I immediately regretted what I said; because the look on Mac’s face was all I needed to know that I’d hurt her. Before I could say anything to apologize, she turned and walked out of the room. I went to follow after her; but Marcus grabbed my arm and, with a surprisingly tender tone, said, “I’d give her a little while, Brian.”
11131111111111111111111111.title: Upstairs

111311111111111111111111111.content:
When I felt like the time was right, I went looking for Mac, to apologize to her. As I went downstairs, I heard her muttering.

I found her sitting at the kitchen table, her head bowed. As I drew closer, I could hear what she was saying, over and over: "God, grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change; the courage to change the things I can; and the wisdom to know the difference."

"What's that?" I asked. "I don't think I've heard that before."

"You wouldn't have," she replied. "I learned it at AA. I figured I'd say it for a while; if I still felt like drinking, I'd call my sponsor."

"I thought you beat it, that you were better."

"Alcoholism isn't a sprint, and it isn't a marathon: It's your life."

I felt about an inch tall. Bad enough I had hurt her feelings: I had damn near made her start drinking again. "I'm sorry, Mac. I went too far, and I hurt you. I don't suppose it matters that I didn't mean to."

"Nobody ever means to. People just say the first thing that comes into their heads, and worry about how it makes people feel later, if at all." She lifted her head. "This isn't ideal for you. I get that. I can even sympathize. The thing is, none of this is ideal for anybody. Mom and Henry can't take you in. And I'm certainly not sending a 13-year-old boy to live with Aaron and his girlfriend. So that leaves me, and the house you grew up in. All I wanted was for the two of you to work things out yourselves. Because you're going to face bigger challenges out in the world when you grow up. Instead,... "

I hugged Mac. "I'll try, sis. I'll try to deserve this."

"You already are. Just try to give me the benefit of the doubt, okay? If being a mother was easy, men would be doing it."
111311111111111111111111111.title: Apologizing to Mac

1113111111111111111111111111.content:
Dinner was ready about an hour later, or I should say Mac returned with take-out an hour later. Things were still tense between me and Marcus, but he had stopped glaring at me whenever I entered the room – I suppose that was progress.

Everyone was downstairs eating some KFC, which I was pleasantly surprised to learn still existed after 27 years. I was in the middle of eating a chicken wing when the phone started ringing. Being the closet, Megan got up and answered the phone.
“Hello?” a brief pause, she said, “Uncle Aaron!”

Getting up from the table, Mac went over and grabbed the phone from Megan. “I was wondering when you’d call, little brother.” With a grin, Mac said, “I’ve been waiting all day for the news.”

Mac pressed the speakerphone button so we could all hear. “Sorry about this, sis; but Becky and I were in a celebratory mood.” Pausing, he said, “We spent the better part of the morning in…”

“Don’t you dare finish that sentence, Aaron; both your nieces are present.”

“Oops, sorry.” Pausing, Aaron said, “Well, long story; Becky and I are engaged.”

Even though I barely knew him, I was happy for Aaron; after all, he was my little (older?) brother. We all took turns congratulating him. Once that was finished, Mac said, “You’ll have to tell us all about it this weekend.”

“Sure thing, sis.” Chuckling, Aaron said, “I’ll talk to you later; I think Becky wants...”

“Aaron!”

“Geez sis, get your mind out of the gutter.” Chuckling, Aaron said, “Becky wants to see a movie; and it starts in 15 minutes.”
1113111111111111111111111111.title: Dinner

11131111111111111111111111113.content:
Sharing a room with Marcus wasn’t my most pleasant experience; he spent most of the night just glaring at me. I figured he was just mad that Mac had made him sleep in a sleeping bag so that I could use the bed. Having a pair of eyes staring at me, especially when they belonged to someone who didn’t like me very much made it difficult to fall asleep. It seemed like forever before I could finally fall asleep...

Only to suddenly be shaken awake; I was certain that Marcus had decided to kill me in my sleep. “Get off me!” I only calmed down once I saw that it was Mac. Sitting up, I looked at her and said, “Geez Mac; you know I don’t like that!”

“Are you okay?” with a chuckle, Mac looked at me and said, “You looked pretty worried for a moment.”

“It’s nothing; I just…thought Marcus was trying to kill me.”

“You don’t have to worry about that; nobody’s going to hurt you, sweetie.” Running her hand through my bed-head, she said, “I just wanted to make sure you were awake; this isn’t something we want to be late for.”

I suddenly remembered the appointment at the courthouse; the one where I’d be declared legally alive once more and, well...my younger sister would become my legal guardian.

**********************


I quickly took a shower and got dressed; making my way downstairs to the kitchen where I found everyone else was already at the kitchen table. I look a seat as Mac placed a plate of pancakes in front of me. “I made them just like the way you liked them.”
A cursory look down showed that was the case; chocolate chip pancakes smothered in whipped cream, maple syrup, and a side of bacon and eggs. Once everyone had eaten, we all got into the car; Marcus and I sat in the middle row while Megan and Allison sat in the back,

Marcus was still acting as though he wanted nothing to do with me; so I paid him no attention either. Instead, I found myself thinking about the fact that my little sister was about to become my legal guardian. Would that mean I had to call her mom now? Would that make Mom my grandma as well?

Everything about the last few days was just confusing and difficult to process; especially the fact that Mac was now old enough to be my mother. Hell, even her best friend Emily had a daughter who was my age.

Emily's daughter. Callie. She seemed pretty cool and cute…

Just like that, I started thinking about Callie; I didn’t realize I’d become lost in thought until I realized we’d arrived. Unbuckling my seat, I was about to get out of the car when I noticed that I had an erection.

Before I could do something to hide it, Marcus blurted out, “Whoa; something got you excited.”

“MARCUS! WATCH YOUR MOUTH!"

While Duncan pulled Marcus aside to lecture him, Mac came over to check on me. God, she was already treating me like a kid. Looking at me, she said, “We'll wait a bit for it to go down"

“As if this whole situation wasn’t embarrassing enough.”

“Were you thinking about Callie?” I felt myself start to blush as my erection stiffened again. Mac could only chuckle at my response. “I’ll tell you what; once we get all this legal stuff taken care of, I’ll call Emily to see if Callie would like to hang out.”

I wanted to make a fuss about Mac teasing me, but the idea of hanging out with Callie sounded nice. “I’d like that.”

Once I was finally calm again, Mac and I rejoined the others at the bottom of the stairs. As much as I didn't want the government thinking I was dead, I was still anxious about Mac, my sister, becoming my legal guardian.
11131111111111111111111111113.title: The Next Day

111311111111111111111111111131.content:
Everyone waited in the reception area outside the Judge’s chambers; I was passing the time just looking around the room when Mac came over and sat next to me. “I just got off the phone with Emily; it seems Callie has been, in her words, nagging her incessantly about seeing you again.”

I could feel my face turn red from a mix of embarrassment and excitement. I’d only just met Callie the other day, but that was enough for us to influence each other. Trying to hide my excitement, I said, “So, uh, what happens next?”

“There’s an indoor go-kart track that just opened up at the mall; Marcus has been wanting to go there for weeks.” Looking at me, Mac said, “I’ll call Emily after we’re done here, and they’ll meet us there.”

I got up to hug Mac, saying, “Thanks Mac, for everything.”

“I’d do anything for you, Brian.” Holding me close, Mac said, “I can't tell you how much it means to me that you're back.”

A young woman, probably a few years younger than Mac, stepped out of the judge’s chambers and came over to us. It didn’t take much for me to realize she was probably the judge’s receptionist. “Mrs. Douglas? The judge is ready for you.”

Mac and I followed the receptionist as the others stayed behind.
111311111111111111111111111131.title: Inside the Courthouse

1113111111111111111111111111311.content:
Given the fact that I had ended up 27 years in the future, I should have figured I would run into more people that I knew years earlier. That didn’t keep me from being surprised, however, when I recognized the judge that we were meeting with. She was older, with a small number of wrinkles and slightly greying of her hair, but I recognized her instantly. “Jessica!”

27 years earlier Jessica Rogers had been this reserved 17-year-old girl who lived across the street from us. She used to babysit for all the families on the block, and I’d be lying if I said I hadn’t had a crush on her at one point.

I barely gave her time to stand up as I ran around the desk and hugged her. While Mac looked on with an annoyed face, having gotten over her shock, looked down and said, “Brian?” kneeling in front of me, she said, “Is that you?”

“Yeah, it’s me.”

Coming up behind me, Mac grabbed my arm and started pulling me back. “That was very inappropriate, young man.”

Once I got over the shock of being reprimanded by my sister, I turned to Jessica and said, “Sorry, I don’t know what came over me.”

Silently acknowledging my apology, Jessica looked at Mac as the two of us sat down across from her. “I feel an interesting story
coming on, Mackenzie.”

“It’s very interesting, Your Honor.” Gesturing to me, Mac said, “It’s probably best if Brian tells the story if he can control himself.”

I briefly glared at Mac before I turned back to Jessica and said, “Well Jessica...”

“Your Honor.” Turning all serious, Jessica said, “I let it slide once, but please call me Your Honor or Judge Thomas.”

Blushing from embarrassment, I said, “Sorry Your Honor.” After composing myself, I said, “The last thing I remembered was playing hide & seek in the woods behind my house. I suddenly lost consciousness before waking up in the hospital; later finding out that 27 years had passed.”

Taking everything in, Judge Thomas turned her attention to Mac and said, “I hesitate to bring this up, but what are the chances this is some kind of trick?”

“Zero; the Hospital confirmed that he is Brian Hawkins, albeit with one minor difference.” Seeing the look on Judge Thomas’ face,
Mac said, “The injury he sustained during the zip line accident isn’t there anymore.”

After looking over the documents that proved my identity, Judge Thomas turned back to us and said, “I suppose the big question now would be – where was he for 27 years and why hasn’t he aged?”
