“We don’t know, Your Honor; and to be quite honest, I’m not interested in searching for answers.” Placing a hand on my shoulder, Mac said, “If something were to fall in our lap so be it; but, as far as my family is concerned, Brian is back and that’s all any of could ask for.”

“I suppose I can’t blame you for that; after all, why look a gift horse in the mouth.” Looking at Mac, Judge Thomas said, “Apart from declaring him legally living again, what else can I do for you?”

“He’s not thrilled about the idea, but I’d also like to petition the court to become his legal guardian.”

“You’ll understand that I can’t just grant you legal guardianship, even if he is your brother.” As she signed some papers, Judge Thomas said, “I’ll contact Social Services and have them send over a caseworker who will check things out.”

Mac and I looked at each other, worried; I don’t know about her, but I was wondering how the caseworker would feel about Marcus’ feelings towards me. Turning back to Judge Thomas, Mac said, “Thank you, Your Honor.”

After thanking Judge Thomas, who pulled me in for a hug this time, Mac and I left with the paperwork declaring me legally alive once more. Allison and Megan both congratulated me, while Marcus gave me a forced smile and begrudgingly congratulated me as well.

Now that everything was taken care of, we were on our way to ride the Go-Karts.
1113111111111111111111111111311.title: Meeting with the Judge

11131111111111111111111111113111.content:
I kept close to Mac as we entered the Mall, as there was something I needed to ask her. “So, um, am I going to have to call you ‘Mom’ from now on?”

“I don’t think that will be necessary.” Chuckling, Mac said, “Besides, I think that would just confuse Mom.”

With a laugh, I said, “I guess you’re right.”

As we made our way through the food court, I noticed Emily and Callie waiting at a nearby table. I made sure that I didn’t get too excited as Callie came up to greet me. “Hey, sup?”

“I’m doing fine, you?”

With a smile and a chuckle, Callie replied, “Ah, can’t complain.”

The two of us kept close together as we followed our respective families around the corner to the arcade. As we walked inside, I was in awe of how expansive it was; not only was there the Go-Kart track and trampolines but a large area filled with video games. “Wow, this is amazing.”

Grabbing my arm, Callie pulled me over to the Go-Kart counter, “You ready to get your butt kicked?”

I’d always been pretty competitive so when Callie said that, I said, “Hey, I'm never ready to lose.” As we signed the waivers, I said, “Just so that you know, I was unstoppable back in the day.”

Turning to me, her hands on her hips in a confident pose, Callie chuckled and said, “Bring it on, old man.”

I’m sure people nearby thought otherwise, but Callie and I were just interested in having a friendly competition. After that, Callie and I made our way to the track where we saw four other kids waiting to ride. The go-karts were a bit more advanced than what I was used to, but I quickly got the hang of it as I passed three of them in rapid succession.

The go-karts allowed me to forget all about everything that happened, even if only for a little while – I was having fun again. Before I could take the lead however, Callie came zooming past; no one had ever been able to pass me, but it looked like I now had a rival. What transpired was a constant back and forth where we jockeyed for the lead. Eventually the session came to an end with Callie having beaten me by less than two seconds.

After getting out of my kart, I walked over and helped Callie from hers. “No one’s ever outpaced me before, you’ve got some mad skill.”

“I spend a lot of time here; but I have to admit you were really good out there.”

As we left the track, I found myself looking at Callie – she seemed so cool and confident...and cute. I had to mentally slap myself to keep from daydreaming again; the last thing I wanted was a repeat of what happened in the car. “Anything else you feel like doing?”

Pointing to the trampolines nearby, Callie said, “You feel like bouncing around for a little while?”

Callie and I ran across the room to the trampolines, thankfully the line to get in wasn’t too long. It wasn’t long before we were inside and jumping around. As I began bouncing, I was relieved to see that trampolines hadn’t changed all that much since my time. Up and down I went, minding my own business as I went up and down in the air. Until…

I was suddenly bumped from behind; I almost lost my footing as Callie said, “Oops, my bad.”

Regaining my footing, I said, “It’s cool.”

I went back to jumping around, only to find myself bumping into Callie a few minutes later. "Oops"

With a chuckle, Callie said, “Hey, at least we’re even now.”

It wasn’t long before she bumped into me again. Every now and then I’d glance over at Callie, seeing how happy she looked. I almost started daydreaming again when…Callie and I bumped into each other once more and we both fell to the ground. Sitting up, I looked at Callie as she sat up next to me. “Sorry about that.”

The two of us looked at each other for a moment until we just started giggling. “It’s all cool, dude.” Getting back to her face, Callie said, “We’re all clumsy on trampolines.”

As I got back to my feet, I noticed Marcus watching us from the sidelines – the look he was giving me was unsettling. While he hadn’t been nice to me since my return, there was something different about the look he was giving me – it was almost threatening. I quickly shelved those thoughts; as I didn’t want Marcus ruining my fun with Callie.

*************************


Eventually our session came to an end; as we were putting our shoes on, I said, “How are you at Street Fighter?”
I honestly had no clue whether Street Fighter was still popular after 27 years; but I was relieved when Callie said, “You wanna find out?”

I was kind of surprised to find that in the 27 years since I’d vanished, they’d only gotten up to Street Fighter 7. But what surprised me even more was how the button layout had changed; there was more of them now. It would be an understand to say that I was clumsy.

After Callie beat me twice in a row, I said, “I give up.”

“Oh come on, we’re having fun.” Smiling, Callie said, “My mom said the older games had a different layout, I can help you if you want.”

I happily accepted Callie’s offer to help, but my attention was soon drawn to Marcus once again. He was standing nearby, giving me the same evil look as before. "Did you understand all that?" Callie's voice brings me back to the present.

I hadn’t been paying attention, but I didn’t want her to know that. "Yes, I think so.”

“I’ll go easy on you.”

As Callie took the seat next to me, I noticed Marcus squinting his eyes – he looked even meaner than before, and angrier. It suddenly dawned on me just what Marcus could mad about right now. Does Marcus have a crush on Callie?
11131111111111111111111111113111.title: Go-Karts

111311111111111111111111111131111.content:
Eventually we all made our way to the Food Court for lunch; Callie and I took our own table while the others sat nearby. I couldn’t help but notice the looks we were getting from Mac and Emily, as if they knew something was going on.

As I took a bite of my cheeseburger, Callie looked at me and said, “Now that you’re back from the dead, are you going to be start school again?”

“I don’t see how I have any choice; I’m only 13 years old.” Putting my sandwich down, I said, “Besides, I’m pretty sure Mac would make me go to school anyway.”

“You’ll certainly have an interesting first couple days; after all, you’d be the oldest student in the school.”

That thought hadn’t occurred to me until just then. “I didn’t think of it like that, but I guess you’re right.” Looking at her, I said, “None of the students were even born before I disappeared.”

“That’s true, but we all grew up hearing about your disappearance.” Leaning closer, Callie said, “If I’m being honest, you’re a bit of a legend around the school yard; a story that older students tell to scare the younger kids.”

I wasn’t particularly thrilled to hear that; looking at her, I said, “What kind of stories do they tell?”

“They’re all basically the same thing; some evil demon found you in the woods and took you away.” Seeing the color drain from my face, Callie said, “But I knew better than to believe those crazy stories.”

“I guess I’ll have to deal with that for a while, huh?”

“Come on, you know how teenagers can be; give it a week and you’ll be old news.” Smiling at me, Callie said, “Then again you are pretty cute, so who knows; you might be popular for all sorts of reasons.”

The two of us realized what Callie had said at the same time; leading both of us to blush as I said, “Y-You think I’m cute?”

While Callie struggled to think of what to say, I noticed Marcus nearby with a pained look on his face. I ignored that for the time being as Callie finally said, “If I’m being on honest, I’ve been thinking about you pretty much nonstop since the hospital.” Leaning closer, Callie said, “I didn’t want to tell you because I figured you didn’t feel that way about me; after all, you did grow up with my mom.”

“Are you kidding?” trying to keep my voice down, I leaned over and said, “I’ve been thinking about you as well.”

“We should probably get to know each other a little better, don’t you think?” Callie tried to hold her excitement as she said, “Who knows, maybe we’ll have some classes together at school.”

Before I could say anything, I felt someone slam into me from behind; causing my drink to spill over when I bumped the table. As I watched the soda spill all over Callie, I noticed Marcus rushing past me with the same angry look. I knew instantly that he was the one that bumped into me - I hate that kid.

Callie’s shirt was covered in soda at this point, her face a mix of embarrassment and anger. I tried my best to help her dry off, but I was careful not to go near her chest. Emily and Mac had rushed over by that point, with Emily saying, “Come on honey, I’ll help you with that.”

While Callie and Emily made their way to the bathroom, I turned to find Mac looking at me. “What was that all about?”
111311111111111111111111111131111.title: Lunchtime

1113111111111111111111111111311111.content:
Quite a few people in the food court were staring at me as Mac took a seat next to me; no doubt thinking that she was a mother about to lecture her son. Seeing Marcus walk out of the bathroom area, glaring at me, he said, “I don’t know Mac, why don’t you talk to your son.” Pointing to him, I said, “He’s the one who bumped me and caused my soda to spill all over Callie.”

“Did you do or say anything that might’ve set him off?” looking at me, Mac said, “I know my son, Brian; he wouldn’t lash out in public without a reason.”

“I haven’t the foggiest idea what could’ve set him off, Mac.” Sighing, as I wiped some soda off my leg, I said, “One moment Callie and I were both saying we thought the other was cute; the next minute she’s covered in soda.”

“I think I know what may have set him off.” Taking a deep breath, Mac said, “Do you remember, growing up, how you had a big crush on our babysitter Kelly, and how upset you got when you found out she had a boyfriend?”

Kelly Roberts was a girl that lived down the street from us; from the time I was 9 years old to 12 years old, she would babysit for Mac and me. I had the biggest crush on her, like Mac said, and was disappointed to find out that she had a boyfriend already. In hindsight it wouldn’t have worked out anyway, since she was 6 years older than me at the time, but it still hurt. “What does that have to do with Marcus hating me?”

“You really don’t see it, do you?” looking at me, Mac said, “Marcus has had a crush on Callie for the last year or so.”

Everything started to make more sense. “Oh boy, I see where you’re going with this.” seeing Marcus come out of the bathroom nearby, I said, “He thinks I’m trying to steal Callie from him?”

“I wouldn’t go that far; after all, he’s only 12 years old.” Sighing, Mac said, “If you truly care for Callie, and I suspect that you do, you shouldn’t let Marcus get in the way of that.”

“I’ll try my best, but he’s not going to make that easy.” Looking at Mac, I said, “Your son hates me, Mac.”

“Marcus doesn’t hate you; he barely knows you.” Looking at me, Mac said, “He just has issues with meeting new people; but he’s not a bad kid.”

I saw Callie walk out of the bathroom at that moment, looking rather annoyed. I decided it was best to go and apologize for what happened. Walking up to her, I said, “I’m so sorry Callie, I must’ve lost my grip on the cup.”

It wasn’t the truth, but I didn’t want to tell her about Marcus. “You got soda all over my favorite top, Brian.” Callie looked at me for a moment, until her annoyed expression started to soften. Taking a deep breath, she said, “But it was an accident, so I forgive you; besides, you tried to help as well.”

I didn’t want Callie to hate me, after all she was the first friend I’d made since coming back. I was relieved when she forgave me, though. “So we’re cool?”

“Yeah, we’re cool.” Looking at me, blushing ever so slightly, Callie said, “I’ll tell you what; how about you come over to my house tomorrow and we can go for a swim in the pool.”

The thought of going swimming was appealing, if only because of the possibility of seeing Callie in a bikini. Trying to hold my excitement, I said, “Sure, I’d love to.”

“Great, I’ll see you tomorrow.”
1113111111111111111111111111311111.title: Fixing Things

11131111111111111111111111113111111.content:
I lay atop of Marcus’ bed scrolling through my phone; grateful that he was spending the night at a friend’s house. In the meantime, I scoured the internet for any advice on what to do when ‘a cute girl invites you her to place.’ Let’s just say the results were less than helpful; eventually I got tired of searching and just stared up at the ceiling.

It wasn’t long before my thoughts turned to Callie, as I quickly started to imagine her wearing a bikini. I quickly quashed those thoughts; having no intention of messing things up with her. Callie was my first real friend in this era and, assuming I didn’t mess anything up, she could end up being my first girlfriend.

My train of thought was interrupted by a knock at the door; turning towards it, I said, “Come in.”

The door opened and Megan walked inside, a smile on her face. “What’s up?”

“Not much; just bored.” looking at her as she got closer, I said, “Did you need something?”

Sitting next to me on the bed, Megan stared at me with a look that reminded me of when Mac was a kid. “I’ve only heard stories about you from Mom; I figured it wouldn’t hurt to get to know the real you.”

“I suppose that wouldn’t hurt; after all, we’re family.” Sitting up, I looked at her and said, “Mac said you did gymnastics, right?”

“Yeah, we have practice tomorrow.”

I couldn’t help but notice the frown on her face, “Is something wrong?”

“No, it’s just...” looking at me, Megan said, “I enjoy gymnastics but I’m not as good as the other girls.”

“That’s nothing to be upset about, Megan; there’s always going to be people better than you.”

"Yeah, but the other girls make fun of me; saying that I'm the worst they've ever seen." sighing, Megan said, "I don't want to tell Mom, because then she might pull me out of gymnastics"

I started to see where this was going. Mac used to be bullied a lot as a kid; the only difference being that she was bullied by boys. I didn’t want to get involved, but then I realized this was my new family; which essentially made me Megan’s older brother. What kind of brother would I be if I didn’t look out for my sister? “You should tell your Mom about this.”

“Bu-“

Before she could finish, I said, “You should tell your instructor, too; they might be able to hep if you explain the situation.” Looking at her, I said, “You shouldn’t let a few bullies keep you from having fun.”

“I guess you’re right.” Jumping off the bed, Megan hugged me and said, “Thanks...big brother.”
11131111111111111111111111113111111.title: Family Bonding, Part I

111311111111111111111111111131111111.content:
I felt awkward about Megan calling me her big brother, since technically I was her uncle; but it still felt nice. Jumping off the bed myself, I decided to go downstairs and check out what types of video games Marcus had. That was where I found Allison playing with some dolls in the living room. Looking up at me, she said, “Do you wanna play?”

I didn't want to play with dolls, I’d came downstairs to play some video games while Marcus was gone. “Uh, actually I was..." I didn't want to play dolls, I was hoping to play one of Marcus's video games while he was away.

Allison suddenly put on the saddest little face ever; complete with puppy dog eyes. She's her mother's daughter. Mac used to do the same thing when she was little, doing everything she could to make it seem like she was going to start crying. I didn’t want to upset Allison, so I hesitantly sat down and said, “I suppose I can for a little while.”

Allison’s face immediately lit up as she handed me one of the dolls.

*************************


Allison and I played for a little while, until I decided to stop and check out Marcus’ games. “Okay.” Getting up, I said, “I’m going to play a game now.”

I felt Allison grab my shorts from behind me, as she whined, “But Peppa Pig will be on soon!”

My first thought was how that show could still be on after almost 30 years. My second thought was that I wasn’t in the mood to deal with a whiny brat. “But I need the TV.”

Allison once again put on her sad face, saying, “Watch it with me.”

I didn't want to upset her, so I gave in and turned the TV to the proper channel so Allison could watch her show. The show was so boring that I almost fell asleep a few times; in stark contrast to the attention Allison was paying the show. Once it was finally over, I got up to use the bathroom; only for Allison to run up and hug me. “Thanks for spending time with me, brudder.”

Once again it felt strange having my little sister’s girls calling me their brother; although I was beginning to suspect that they were using me to compensate for Marcus’ lack of attention. It did, however, feel nice to be part of a family again. Hugging her back, I said, “No problem.”

After coming out of the bathroom, I turned my attention to Marcus’ videogames. I quickly realized there were no cases as I focused on the oddly shaped console – looking like a basketball. "What the hell?"

"Mom wouldn't like you saying that"

Startled, I turned around and saw Megan walking in from the landing. “Sorry.”

“Marcus likes all his games in digital form; he says physical copies take up space.” Pressing a button the top, she said, “By the way, that’s how you turn on the Sony PlaySphere."

“Thanks.”

As Megan walked up the stairs, I thought about the name of the new console – Sony must’ve done away with the Playstation at some point. While scrolling through the library interface, I noticed several surprising things. Instead of the usual preteen stuff like Call of Duty or Fortnite, I saw that Marcus had mostly platformers and some weird Japanese games.

I couldn’t help but chuckle when I saw Final Fantasy XXX listed on the screen. “They seriously still make those?”

I also some more obscure titles - Aura Break, AlienSword Tales, etc. I realized something about Marcus as I looked through his games. “He must be a closeted nerd; that might explain his antisocial behavior.”
111311111111111111111111111131111111.title: Family Bonding, Part II (Allison)

1113111111111111111111111111311111111.content:
Due in large part to my unfamiliarity with the games, I only played them for 15 minutes or so before stopping. I made a mental note to ask Marcus about them, until I realized he’d probably kill me for touching his stuff. Oh well, thinking to myself, I’ll just talk to Callie about it tomorrow.

Walking out of the family room, I was about to go upstairs until dinner when I heard a noise coming from down the hall. Curious what the noise was, I followed it to what used to be my dad’s office. Poking my head inside, I saw Duncan sitting behind the desk talking with someone on the phone. “Yeah, I can take a look at that once I’m back in the office.” Glancing at me, still on the phone, he said, “I’m dealing with some family stuff right now, so I’m afraid that takes priority.”

Walking further into the room, I sat down on the couch by the window as Duncan finished his call. Once he was finished, I said,
“Sounds like you’ve got a lot of work waiting for you, huh?”

“No more than usual.” Getting up to join me on the couch, Duncan said, “How are you coping with everything?”

“Pretty good, I guess; despite the fact that Marcus looks like he wants to kill me.” Looking at Duncan, I said, “I know he’s my nephew and everything; but his attitude makes it really hard to be around him.”

Duncan looked at me for a moment, as if he were trying to figure out what to say next. After a moment, he said, “I suppose it
doesn’t help that he thinks you’re stealing his girlfriend.”

I was about to snap at Duncan for saying that, until I realized he was only joking. “Hey; if I’d known Marcus liked Callie, I would’ve done things differently.” Pausing, I said, “As it is, I’m not sure she feels the same about me.”

“Oh, I’m pretty sure she does, Brian.” With a smile, Duncan said, “I saw the way she was looking at you on the trampolines; it seems pretty obvious that she has feelings for you.”

“Don’t get me wrong, I’m thrilled about that; but it seems a bit strange.” sighing, I said, “We’ve only known each other a few days; add to that the fact that I grew up with her mom.”

“The heart wants what the heart wants, Brian.” Taking a breath, Duncan said, “Callie, just like your nieces and nephew, grew up hearing stories about you. I think she fell in love with the idea of you a long time ago; now she’s got a chance to be with the real deal.”

Taking that to heart, I said, “I’m supposed to hang out at her house tomorrow; what should I do if she, you know, tries to kiss me or
something?”

“You’re a teenage boy, Brian; that’s not something you need me to answer.” Placing a hand on my shoulder, Duncan said, “Just go with the flow, do what feels right.”

“Thanks, Duncan.” Getting to my feet, I said, “I really appreciate the advice.”

With a big smile on his face, Duncan said, “Hey, what are brother in laws for.”
1113111111111111111111111111311111111.title: Family Bonding, Part III (Duncan)

11131111111111111111111111113111111111.content:
I was chomping at the bit this morning, checking the time constantly. Megan, Duncan, and Mac all knew the reason; while Allison was more than a little confused why I was acting that way. The only response anyone, including me, would give her was – You’ll understand when you’re older.

Finally, the time came for us to leave, I was standing in front of the door holding a towel and a bag with a change of clothes. I saw Mac taking her sweet time walking down the hall, so I said, “Come on Mac, can you walk any slower?”

“I don’t know.” Intentionally slowing down some more, Mac said, “Does this help?”

“Very funny, Mac; now seriously, can you walk faster?” Seeing the amused look on Mac’s face, I curtly said, “What’s so funny?”

“Oh nothing, I just haven’t seen you this excited to go to someone’s house since Andrea’s attractive cousin was spending the weekend.” Looking to me, as she opened the door, she said, “You really have a thing for the woman in that family, don’t you?”

I chose not to comment on that, but deep down I suspected Mac was right; it did seem as though every crush I’d ever had was on members of Callie’s family. Once we got to Callie’s house, I jumped out of the car before it came to a complete stop. God, I hope Callie isn’t watching right now. Emily was waiting the door, dressed in her scrubs, with a dejected look on her face. I got worried for a moment, especially as she turned to Mac and said, “I’ve been called in for emergency surgery.”

“Oh.” Looking towards me, Mac said, “Does that mean Brian can’t hang out with Callie?”

“I haven’t got a problem with them being here alone; it’s not like they’re going to do anything inappropriate.” Turning to me, Emily said, “Callie’s out back by the pool; why don’t you head out there.”

“Thanks, Emily.” As an afterthought, I turned to Mac and said, “See you later, Mac.”

Running through the house, I caught a glimpse of the backyard and knew I was going in the right direction. Stepping out onto the patio, I only managed to take a few steps before stopping in my tracks. Callie was looking at me with a smile on her face; wearing a bathing suit that made her look like the most beautiful woman I’d ever seen in my life.
11131111111111111111111111113111111111.title: Going to Callie's

choices: Putting My Foot in My Mouth
111311111111111111111111111131111111111.content:
The two of us stood on the pool deck for a few moments, just staring at each other. I could feel something stirring in my pants, I just hoped Callie didn’t notice it. After a moment, she walked over and said, “So what do you think?”

In that moment I wasn’t sure what exactly she was referring to, so I tried my best. “I’m a little jealous; I always wanted a pool in my backyard.”

With a chuckle, Callie said, “I’m not talking about the pool, dummy.” Smiling, gesturing to her appearance, Callie said, “How do I look?”

“Oh, right.” Realizing my mistake caused me to blush even more than I already was. “Y-You look good.”

“Good?” with a frown, Callie said, “I’m the first girl you’ve seen in a bikini in close to 30 years, and all you can say is good?”

If I was being honest, I didn’t have much experience seeing girls in bikinis prior to my disappearance. My only close female friend was Carrie, and she typically wore a men’s suit and t-shirt in the water. I suppose, in hindsight, that should’ve been my first clue that she was a lesbian. “You look great, Callie; it’s just...I wasn’t expecting you to look like that.”

“Hey, just because I act all macho doesn’t mean I don’t have a feminine side.” Walking over with a glass of lemonade, Callie said, “I’m still a girl, Brian; I can show off my figure when I feel like it.”

I started to worry that Callie was going to focus on my perceived slight the entire time. “Give me a break, Callie; like you said, I haven’t been around girl’s for a while.”

Callie just stared at me for a moment, her face all serious, until she smiled and said, “Relax, I’m just messing with you.” Leading me towards the pool, she said, “To be honest, I don’t really like wearing bikinis; I just thought today would be an appropriate time to do so.”

******************************


The two of us spent the better part of the next two hours both in and out of the pool; we played Marco Polo, had a cannon ball contest, we even just sat in the chairs and talked. Eventually the topic of Marcus came up, to which Callie said, “I kind of figured he would lash out if he saw us hanging out together.”

“That kid scares me to death; I have trouble sleeping at night because I’m afraid he’s going to kill me or something.” Looking at Callie, I said, “I’m terrified of what he might do when we start dating.”

I was unfortunate enough to have Callie staring right at me as she spit out her lemonade all over my face. While I went to wipe off the lemonade, Callie just stared at me. “What do you mean when we start dating?”
111311111111111111111111111131111111111.title: Hanging with Callie

1113111111111111111111111111311111111111.content:
My heart was racing as I struggled to come up with a suitable response. Shit, did I really just say that out loud? Callie, for her part, was looking at me funny as well, “Brian?”

I struggled to think of a way out of this as I focused, once more, on Callie sitting in the chair across from me. Seeing her looking amazing in her bikini wasn’t helping, as I felt something growing in my swim trunks. I was suddenly reminded of what Duncan had told me the previous night – “The heart wants what the heart wants.”

So, without thinking, I leaned over and pressed my lips against Callie’s. I started panicking as I could feel her body tensing up, Idiot, the first girl to ever show interest in you, and you just blew it! I was about to pull away and apologize when, out of nowhere, Callie gradually started returning my kiss – her lips pressing against mine as she maneuvered herself next to me on my chair.

Time seemed to slow down for us as we kissed; but, frankly, I didn’t really care. All I could think about was sharing this incredible moment with the girl I loved. Unfortunately for both of us, that meant neither of us realized someone else had entered the backyard. “Callie, do you know...WHO THE HELL ARE YOU!?”

Callie and I immediately broke our kiss; turning to find an angry man standing at the back door holding a small tool bag in one hand. Seeing the look on the man’s face, I slowly started to get up, which only served to enrage him even more. The man had dropped his bag and was moving towards me before I’d even cleared the chairs. I thought he was going to kill me, until
Callie stepped between and said, “Dad, wait!”

"Dad?” looking at Callie, I said, “I thought Emily wasn’t married?”

Ignoring my comment for a moment, Callie looked at the man and said, “Dad; this is Brian, Mom’s friend from childhood. I know she told you he was back, I was in the kitchen when she did so.” Turning her attention back to me, Callie said, “Brian; this is my dad, Cameron. He and Mom, well, they were married shortly before I was born but divorced when I was 3 years old.”

“I came over to fix your mother’s sink. But,” turning to me, Cameron said, “I would’ve appreciated a heads up about there being a boy alone with my daughter. "

I knew I was in hot water with Cameron; if I said or did anything wrong, it’d probably make him want to kill me. After all seeing a strange boy kissing your daughter wasn’t the best way to make an introduction.
1113111111111111111111111111311111111111.title: Putting My Foot in My Mouth

1113111111111111111111111111311111111111.content:
Cameron wasn’t too keen on Callie and I being left alone, so he suggested that we come inside and watch a movie. I say suggested, but he actually politely demanded that we do that. After almost an hour had passed, I got it in my head that I should go try and smooth things over with Cameron.

Getting up from the couch, I walked into the kitchen to find a jumble of pipes lying on the kitchen floor. Walking up to Cameron, who was lying on his back under the counter, I said, “Do you need any help, sir?”

Cameron maneuvered himself just enough to see me; the annoyed look on his face giving way to something less menacing. “I don’t suppose you know anything about fixing a leaky sink, do you?”

“Actually, yeah I do.” Sitting on the floor next to Cameron, I said, “I had to help my Dad fix our bathroom sink when I was 9 years old.”

Cameron didn’t say anything for a moment as he went back to work, until he reached out his hand and said, “Give me that towel by your foot, okay?”

Handing him the towel, I said, “I’m sorry about before, sir; it’s just I really like Callie.” With a nervous chuckle, I said, “It sounds weird when I say that; having feelings for the daughter of a girl whose diapers I used to change as a toddler.”

“I suppose I can’t fault you for acting on your feelings.” Pulling himself out of from under the sink, Cameron said, “Hell at least you were caught out by the pool; Emily’s father caught us making out on her bed.”

“I suppose we got off easy, compared to you guys.” With a chuckle, I said, “I imagine Emily’s father wasn’t too happy after that.”

“No, he most certainly wasn’t.” Chuckling, Cameron said, “If you thought I was mad; just be glad I didn’t have a 9 iron in my hands.”

The two of us continued talking as we worked to fix the sink; having the typical conversation one would have with the father of a girl you liked. By the time we’d fixed the problem with the sink, Cameron and I were on good terms. We were packing away the tools when Callie walked into the kitchen, “I didn’t hear any yelling; does that mean everything’s cool?”

“Yeah; everything’s cool, sweetie.” Smiling, Cameron said, “If you want to date Brian, I won’t stop you.”

As she started walking towards me, Callie said, “Thanks, Dad.”

The two of us made out for a brief moment until Cameron interrupted us by saying, “Hey, just because I’m okay with it doesn’t mean I want to see you two making out with each other.”
1113111111111111111111111111311111111111.title: Brian Talks with Cameron

1113111111111111111111111111311111111111.content:
Since Emily wasn't home yet, Cameron stayed to keep an eye on me and Callie. The two of us decided to watch something on tv.

Flipping through the channels, I was unable to find anything on TV. Before long, Callie gently removed the remote from my hand. "I'm fine with just being with you" she says as she scoots closer.

As she cuddles up to me, her head and damp hair resting on my shoulder, I wrap my arm around her waist. We stayed like that for a while; Cameron didn't really seem to have a problem with us cuddling.

Eventually Emily arrives home, and then notices Cameron. "I fixed the sink" Cameron says.

"I appreciate it" Emily replies bluntly, although she barely looks at Cameron. "Didn't expect you to still be here however" she adds

"Well do you expect a father to just leave his daughter alone with a boy?" Cameron says coldly

"He had my permission to be here" Emily replies

"Exactly" Cameron quickly changes the tone of his voice when Emipy gives him a cold look "I mean he ain't bad or anything just I caught them kissing that's all"

Both Callie and I blushed furiously as we heard Cameron tell Emily about our kiss.

"Oh really?" says Emily

"I'll be on my way then.... take care" Cameron says before leaving.

Callie and I, holding hands, approach Emily anxiously.

"So you two are an item now?" Emily says. She chuckles at the blush that appears on both of our faces. "I'm happy for the two of you, but I want to lay down some ground rules"

Both Callie and I felt embarrassed as Emily layed down several rules that boiled down to "don't do anything funny when there's no adult around".

"Mom..." Callie was about to ask Emily, but her mother seemed to have read her mind.

"Yes, you two can kiss - under adult supervision"

Relieved by Emily's answer, Callie and I made out for a bit before Emily asked if we wanted something to eat.
1113111111111111111111111111311111111111.title: Later On

choices: A Few Days Later (Shopping for School Supplies)
1113111111111111111111111111311111111111.content:
Callie and I hung out for a little longer until Emily reminded her daughter that she needed to check on the neighbors cat. Callie gave me a quick kiss before leaving.

After a few minutes of awkward silence, Emily looked at me and said, "So, you're dating my daughter now?"

"Yeah, I guess I am." Getting worried, I said, "That's not going to be a problem, is it?"

Emily started chuckling as she shook her head, "If I had a problem with it, you wouldn't still be sitting on my couch." Sitting next to me, Emily said, "Never in my wildest dreams did I think my best friend's older brother would someday be dating my daughter."

"Yeah, I imagine that was quite the shock for you." With a chuckle, I said, "Especially since you used to have a crush on me."

Emily was, unfortunately for her, drinking a soda when I said that. As soda sprayed out of her mouth, she looked at me and said, "How do you know about that?"

"Mac told me once; after I noticed you acting strangely around me." Shrugging, I said, "I didn't believe her, so I asked Amelia and she basically confirmed it."

Her face beet red with embarrassment, Emily said, "Wow, I don't know what's worse; Mac telling you something I made her swear not to, or that I used to have a crush on my daughter's boyfriend."

"Lets just add it to the long list of things that are different now." With a smile on my face, I continued, "For what it's worth; while I didn't have a crush on you growing up, I did care about you very much. I still do."

Placing her hand on mine, Emily said, "I care about you too, Brian; although not in the same way as I used to."
1113111111111111111111111111311111111111.title: Brief talk with Emily

1113111111111111111111111111311111111111.content:
I’d been home for almost 25 minutes; casually watching TV in the family room while Emily and Mac were talking in the kitchen. I could only hear bits and pieces, but I had my suspicions about what they were talking about. Eventually Emily left and Mac joined me in the family room, “So, I heard you’re dating my god-daughter now?”

“I wouldn’t say we’re dating yet, Mac.” Muting the TV, I sat back and said, “All we’ve done so far is make out.”

“This is true; but that’s still a big step, especially for you.” Looking at me with a smile on her face, Mac said, “I remember how weirded out you were after kissing Carrie; and for you that was less than a year ago.”

Mac was right; I was weirded out after kissing Carrie. Not because I’d just kissed a girl, but because of who I’d kissed. Carrie had been one of my closest friends for years; to me she’d been one of the guys. “That whole thing with Carrie felt forced, neither of us really wanted to do it.” Sighing, I said, “But with Callie it was different; we both wanted it to happen.”

“I’m really happy for you, Brian; with everything going on you deserve some happiness. But,” turning serious, Mac said, “There’s one thing I suspect you haven’t thought of.”

It didn’t take a genius to realize what Mac was referring to – Marcus. Looking at her, I said, “Do I have to tell him? He’s just going to hate me even more.”

“It’s better to just get it over with, Brian; instead of him finding out some other way.”

Taking note of the diplomatic tone Mac was using, I chuckled and said, “You know, you’ve really got this mom thing down.”

“Yeah, that’s what happens when you’re raising 3 children.” Getting up from the couch, Mac said, “No come on, Marcus is upstairs in your room; why don’t you go talk to him.”

I wanted to resist but sensed there was no getting out of this. With a heavy sigh, I walked up the stairs to our bedroom. Walking inside, I found Marcus watching a movie on the TV. “Hey Marcus, can we talk for a moment?”

Muting the TV, in a surprisingly calm tone, Marcus looked at me and said, “Sure, I guess.”

“There’s no easy way to say this; especially given your feelings on the matter.” Sitting next to him, I said, “Callie and I...are kind of a couple now.”

1113111111111111111111111111311111111111.content:
I fully expected Marcus to react poorly, but even I was caught off guard by what happened next. Before I could even react, Marcus lashed out and punched me in the nose – the pain and the crunching noise told me it was broken. I quickly moved to block another punch, which led to me falling off the bed.

I was too stunned to do anything as Marcus hit me repeatedly. A few seconds went by before the noise attracted some attention; out of the corner of my eye I could see Megan running into the room. “Marcus, stop!”

I watched as Marcus shoved Megan to the side, causing her to slam her head on the floor. Before Marcus could react, I shoved him aside and got to my feet; grabbing Megan as I made my way to the door. Duncan and Mac must’ve heard the commotion because they rounded the corner just as we came out of the room.

Taking one look at my nose, Mac said, “What happened?”

“I told Marcus that Callie and I were dating; and he, uh, didn’t take it very well.”

While Mac quickly tended to my nose, Duncan went inside the room and closed the door. I listened intently as he yelled at Marcus, “What is wrong with you, young man?”

“He stole my girlfriend!”

“That doesn’t give you the right to break someone’s nose, Marcus.” Sighing, Duncan said, “Besides, we’ve talked about this; I know you have feelings for Callie, but she doesn’t feel that way about you.”

I stopped paying attention to that conversation as Mac returned with an ample amount of toilet paper. Handing it to me, she said, “Here, this’ll help control the bleeding until we get to the hospital.”

“The hospital?”

“Yes Brian, the hospital.” Helping me to my feet, Mac said, “Your nose is broken; and I think you’d be better off having a professional set it.”

I reluctantly realized that Mac was right and followed her down the stairs. We barely made it to the front door before Megan came running down the stairs, “I’m coming with you.”

Mac looked as though she was going to protest, but decided against it, “Okay sweetie, you can come along.”

114.content:
Upon waking up, I found myself staring up at a white ceiling before realizing that I was in a hospital room. Looking around the room, I said to myself, How'd I get here?

Turning over to see if there was anyone around, I suddenly realized that everything seemed off – as if everything around me, the bed included, was bigger than it should have been. “What's going on?”

The voice that came out of my mouth gave me pause; it didn’t sound like mine but still surrounded familiar. “What's wrong with my voice?”

After once again hearing the high-pitched, and squeaky, voice coming from my mouth I instinctively covered my mouth with my hands. Only then did I realize that my hands looked funny too - my fingers seemed tiny. Suddenly a young woman, wearing nurses scrubs, walked into the room. “Is everything okay, sweetie?”

I found that I had to look up at the woman; despite appearing to be in her 20s, she seemed much taller than I expected. Looking at her, with my funny voice, I said, “What’s wrong with me?”

“There’s nothing to be scared of, sweetie.” Kneeling in front of me, the nurse said, “I’m sure we’ll find your Mommy and Daddy soon.”

I was started to get annoyed with how the nurse was speaking to me – like I was a child or something. “I’m not a baby.”

“Of course not, sweetie.” Chuckling, the nurse said, “You're a big boy after all.”

Something was definitely wrong; what with everything appearing bigger, my voice sounding different, and the way the nurse was speaking to me. Before I could ask what was going on, she looked at me and said, “How old are you, sweetheart?”

"13."

“You’re using those big boy numbers, I see.” Giggling, the nurse said, “But we really need to know your age.”

“Jesus, I’m 13 years old!” starting to get worried, I said, “Why, how old do I look?”

Looking confused, the nurse said, “If I had to venture a guess, I’d said no older than 6 years old.”

I went silent as the nurse handed me a mirror. Taking it in my hands, I looked at it and couldn’t see my reflection in it at all. Well I did, but not the one I normally saw. Instead of my 13 year old self, I saw a little kid staring back at me. Somehow I’d turned into a little kid. “What the…”

My screams kept me from finishing that sentence; the nurse tried unsuccessfully to calm me down. I was inconsolable as I started crying. The nurse, sitting in bed next to me, said, “It’s ok sweetie, we'll figure this out".

Managing to calm down ever so slightly, I said, “I want my Mom."

“Sure thing, sweetie; do you have a number for us?”

The nurse left a few minutes later to call the number I’d given her. Once I was alone again, I picked up the mirror and stared at my reflection. I was confused as to what had happened to me. It suddenly dawned on me that I was now the same age as Mac.

*********************************


After what seemed like an eternity, the nurse walked into the room and said, “Sweetie, there’s someone here to see you.”

I look at the nurse as someone else enters the room. There I saw...
114.title: A Surprising Twist

1141.content:
I watched as a teenage girl, around the age I was supposed to be, walked into the room. Looking at her, anxiously, I wondered who she was and why she was here. “Hello?”

Walking closer to me, the girl said, “Hi there.”

Looking at the girl as she approached, I had to admit that she looked pretty cute; wearing a skirt and a shirt that showed a modest amount of cleavage. As I looked at her, I thought there was something familiar about her. Growing concerned, I said,
“Where’s my mom?”

Stopping at my bedside, the girl ran her hand through my hair, “You don’t need to be afraid, we’ll help you find your parents.”
Looking at me for a moment, she said, “It’s weird, I can’t shake the feeling that I know you from somewhere.”

With a feint smile, I said, “I feel the same way.”

The girl stared at me for a moment until she gasped and said, “I’m sorry, I totally forgot to introduce myself.” Smiling, she said, “My name’s Mackenzie Hawkins, but everyone just calls me Mac.”

There’s no way I could have heard that right; no way this teenage girl was...my baby sister. Why was she suddenly a teenager, and why was she suddenly so girly? Before I could think about what to say next, I said, “Mac it’s me, Brian!”

I noticed Mac’s concerned face briefly turn angry; forcing herself to smile, she said, “Can we not play this game?”

“I’m serious, I’m your brother!” my voice getting louder, I said, “I taught you and Emily how to ride a bike! You had this teddy bear that you’d sleep with and take to school with you every day!”

Clearly not amused, Mac faked a chuckle and said, “Everyone has a teddy bear when they’re little.”

“Yeah, but you named yours after me; so you’d always feel like I was watching over you when you were lonely.”

Silence filled the room; until, after several seconds, Mac’s eyes went wide. "Oh my God!" Wrapping her arms around me in a tight hug, she said, “It’s really you!”

I struggled to breath under her tight grasp, as tears fell down her cheeks. “Mac, you’re squeezing me.”

Mac loosened her grip as she stared at me, looking rather upset. “Where have you been!?”

“What are you talking about? One minute we were playing hide & seek, the next minute I found myself here.” Confused, I looked at her and said, “How’d you get so big?”

“Brian, you’ve been missing for close to 7 years.” Wiping tears from her face, I said, “Why do you look like a 6-year-old?”

“How has it been 7 years; when it’s only been a few hours for me.” Looking at her, I said, “As for your other question, I haven’t the faintest idea why I’m suddenly 6 years old again.”

Suddenly, Mac lifted me out of the hospital bed; causing me to yell out as she shifted me in her arms, “Hey, put me down!”

“Don’t worry, everything’s going to be okay; we’ll figure this out together.” Planting a kiss on my forehead as she held me close, Mac said, “I’m never going to let anything bad happen to to you ever again.”

Mac’s words were so direct that it started to bother me; almost as much as the fact that my sister was now older than me and treating me like a little kid. Looking at her, I said, “Where's Mom and Dad?”

Setting my back on the bed, Mac said, “Mom’s waiting outside; she can’t really do walk very fast at the moment.”

“What about Dad?”

Forcing a smile on her face, Mac said, “We-We’ll talk about that later; for now, Mom needs to see you.”

I watched as Mac turned and left the room; leaving me there to decide whether I should follow after her or wait.
1141.title: Mac, but she's now 13

choices: Later On (After talking with the doctors)
11412.content:
It probably wasn’t my smartest idea in retrospect, but I got it in my head to follow Mac. Jumping out of bed, I let out a yelp when I hit the floor – a painful reminder that I was now much shorter than I’d been only hours earlier. Running towards the door, I could hear Mac talking with someone outside, “Mom, you’ve got to believe me; that little boy they called us about is Brian.”

The biggest smile in the world formed on m face as I heard Mom’s voice; only to be somewhat dampened as I heard what she had to say, “What you’re saying isn’t possible, Mackenzie; if your brother were still alive he’d be 7 years older, not 7 years younger.”

Sensing that Mac was in over her head, I walked out of the room – stopping in my tracks when I saw mom standing nearby. She looked pretty much the same despite 7 years having passed; but what surprised me the most was her large baby bump. Feeling uncertain, I said, “Mom?”

Mom looked at me for a few moments, and I mean really looked at me. The longer she looked at me, the more I sensed that she was starting to realize Mac was telling the truth. Falling to her knees, Mom said, “Brian, is that really you?”
Nodding my head, I ran over and buried myself in her arms, “Mom!”

Mom held me in her arms as tears started streaming down her face. Looking at me, touching my face, she said, “How is this possible?”

“I-I don’t know, Mom.” Tearing up, I said, “But it’s really me, I promise.”

Holding me close again, Mom said, “I know, sweetie; I’d recognized that adorable smile anywhere.”

I suddenly felt Mac joining in the hug; if any of the hospital staff was annoyed by the sight of three people crying and hugging in the middle of the hall, they didn’t say anything. Even if they did, I couldn’t care less – I felt safe in my Mom’s arms once again.
